<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler>Issachar</jLink></jLink></jLink> led <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for 23 year. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink></jLink></jLink> and his 30 donkey riding sons lead <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for 22 years. Then the Israelites worshiped pagan gods again. God sold them to the Philistines and the Ammonites. They oppressed the Israelites for 18 years. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> cries to God for help. God says let your other gods help you. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> purges the pagan god worshiping and serves God. God could bear <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s suffering no more. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink></jLink></jLink> leaders declared the leader of the attack against the Ammonites will rule <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1568I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1568I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1568I' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink></jLink></jLink>, was rejected by his family because his mother was a prostitute. But when the Ammonites attacked, his family wanted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> again because he was a great warrior. They offered to make <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> leader of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1568I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1568I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1568I' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink></jLink></jLink> in exchange for his services, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> accepted. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> repeats his words to God in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks the Ammonite king why he is attacking. The king replied that the Israelites took their land. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> replies with a summarized account of how <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> obtained the land, and adding God, the god of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, gave it to them. He challenges that wouldn't the king take what his god Chemosh gives him? <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks why the king did nothing for the 300 years until now that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> owned the land. The king ignores <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s reply.  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> vowed that he would sacrifice as a burnt offering whatever greeted him from his house when he returned home if God would deliver the Ammonites to him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> subdues the Ammonites. His daughter, his only child, dances out to greet him at his house. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> tells his daughter she must die because of his vow to God. His daughter agrees, but requests two months to wander and weep (because she didn't marry) with her friends. After two months, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> fulfils his vow. This explains why the young women of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> go out for four days.

Ephraimites are pissed off to the point of attacking because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> didn't call them to fight against the Ammonites. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> claims he did call, but attacked the Ammonites only with the Gileadites when he saw he was not getting any help.  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> then led the Gileadites against the Ephraimites because the Ephraimites had called the Galeadites “renegades”. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> conquers them, and kills off survivors by identifying their accent. 42,000 Ephaimites are killed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink></jLink></jLink> leads <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> six years, then dies. Then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink></jLink></jLink> of Bethlehem led <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for seven years. He had 30 sons and 30 daughters. He married the sons and daughters outside his clan. Then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink></jLink></jLink> led <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for ten years. Then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink></jLink></jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1985' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1985' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1985' clickHandler>Hillel</jLink></jLink></jLink> led <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for eight years. He had 40 sons and 30 grandsons who rode on seventy donkeys.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> did evil, so God punishes them for 40 years through the hands of the Philistines. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> of the Danites had a sterile wife. The Angel of God appeared to his wife and said she will have a son, so she should not drink fermented drinks or eat anything unclean. The boy will be a Nazirite of God. No razor should be used on his head. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> prayed that God would provide more information on how to raise the boy. The Angel of God appears again. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks Him what should they do with the boy. God ignores his question and replies that his wife must do what He told her. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> offers a goat for a meal. God says make a burnt offering instead. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks his name, but is told it's beyond understanding. God ascends toward heaven in the flame. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and his wife realize they have seen God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4495' clickHandler>Manoah</jLink></jLink></jLink> is afraid of dying for the sight. His wife says they'd already be dead if that were the case. She gives birth to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> grew up blessed by God, and felt the Spirit of God.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>, through the will of God, finds a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink></jLink></jLink> woman that he wants to be his wife in Timnah. While taking his parents to meet her, a lion jumps out at him. With the Spirit of God in him, he tears the lion apart with his bare hands, but doesn't tell his parents this. Later, on his way returning to marry her, he got honey out of the lion carcass for him and his parents to eat without informing them of its origin. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> prepared a customary feast. He was given 30 companions. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> makes a bet with the 30 companions for clothing. The bet involves deciphering a riddle about the honey in the lion carcass that only he knows about. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> gives them seven days to answer. After three days, fearing loss, the companions threaten <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s wife with death to her and her father to provoke her to get the answer from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>. After 4 days of whining, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> relents and gives his wife the answer, which she, in turn, gives to the companions. The companions answer the riddle. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> immediately knows that his wife revealed the answer. He says to the companions “If you had not plowed my heifer, you would not have solved my riddle.” <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler>So</jLink></jLink></jLink> the Spirit of God helps him fulfill his bet debt by killing 30 Ashkelonions. The companions get paid with the plunder from the 30 men. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> went to his father's house burning with anger. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s wife is given to his friend that attended him at the wedding [by her father, according to the next chapter].

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> goes to visit his wife, but her father stops him, saying that he thought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> hated her, and so he gave her to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s friend. Then her father offered his other daughter to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> was extremely angry at this. He caught 300 foxes, tied them tail to tail in pairs, and fastened a torch to each tail pair. He let them loose in the fields of grain, vineyards, and olive groves of the Philistines. The Philistines asked whom was responsible, which some people replied that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> had done this because his wife was given away by her father. Hearing this, the Philistines burned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s wife and her father to death. To which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> thirsted for revenge, and slaughtered many of the Philistines. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> camped in a cave. The Philistines camped in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judah</jLink></jLink></jLink> men heard that the Philistines wanted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>, so they went to retrieve him to avoid bloodshed. They tied him up and began to take him to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink></jLink></jLink> camp. As they approached the camp, the Spirit of God came upon him, and the ropes burnt off him. He found a donkey's jawbone and proceeded to kill 1000 men with it. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> is thirsty, so he calls out to God is God's intention for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> to die of thirst? God opens a spring for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> from which to drink. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> leads <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for 20 years.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> visits a prostitute in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The townsfolk discover he is there and make plans to kill him in the morning, and they laid in wait for him at the city gate. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> got up in the middle of the night and left <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink></jLink></jLink>, tearing the doors of the city gate as he left. Later, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> fell in love with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler>Delilah</jLink></jLink></jLink> from the Valley of Sorek. The rulers of the Philistines bribed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler>Delilah</jLink></jLink></jLink> to find out how <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> could be subdued in turn for a large reward of silver. In a series of three different times, she asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> how he can be subdued. Each time <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> gives a different answer. Each time, she tries to subdue him in that way and then invites the Philistines over to attack him. Each time, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> breaks free. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler>Delilah</jLink></jLink></jLink> proceeds to nag him day after day for the real way to subdue him until he can take no more nagging and finally reveals the true secret of his strength (his hair) and how to subdue himself. Then one night when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> was asleep, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler>Delilah</jLink></jLink></jLink> had someone shave <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s head and she called the Philistines in to take him. God left <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> since his hair was cut. They captured him and gouged out his eyes and sent him to prison. While in prison, his hair started to grow back. The Philistines assembled to sacrifice to their god Dagon and celebrate the capture of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink>. They brought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> out and he performed for them. While resting against a pillar, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> prayed to God for one last burst of strength to take revenge for his eyes. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> pushes two pillars down, collapsing the temple and killing over 3000 men and women including himself. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink></jLink></jLink> had lead <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> for 20 years.

In a time when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> had no king, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink></jLink></jLink> told his mother that he stole her missing silver. His mother blessed him and decided to consecrate some of the silver by turning it into a carved image and an idol that were put in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s house. At <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s shrine, one of his sons served as a priest. A traveling Levite left the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judah</jLink></jLink></jLink> clan in Bethlehem and stopped by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s house. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink> offered him a little silver, his food, and his clothes to live with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Levite agreed and was installed as a priest in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s house. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink> thought God would bless him for that.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> still had no king. The Danites were wandering around looking for their inheritance land. Some Danite spies came across <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s house and spent the night there. The spies recognized the Levite and asked him if their journey would be successful, to which the Levite said God approved their journey. The spies continued and found a city and land ripe for the taking, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3889' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3889' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3889' clickHandler>Laish</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The spies reported and the Danites immediately headed for attack. They stopped by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s house, stole his instruments of worship including the idol and carved image, and convinced the Levite to come with them. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and some men caught up with the Danites, but realized there was nothing he could do about the theft if he wanted to keep his life. The Danites attacked the peaceful and unsuspecting city of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3889' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3889' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3889' clickHandler>Laish</jLink></jLink></jLink>, burning it to the ground. The city was rebuilt and named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink></jLink></jLink>. They continued to use <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4318G' clickHandler>Micah</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s instruments of worship.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> still had no king. A Levite took a concubine from Bethlehem. She was unfaithful and returned to her father. Four months later the Levite went to her father's house. The father persuaded the Levite to stay longer than he intended, but then finally left in the afternoon one day toward Jebus (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>). As nightfall approached, they passed up a Jebusite city in favor of an Israelite city that they reached later, Gibeah. They waited in the town square for some time, but no one invited them to rest at their house. An old man finally invited them into his home for the night. Wicked men of the city began to surround the old man's house, demanding that he send the Levite out so they could have sex with him. Instead, the old man offers his virgin daughter and the Levite's concubine. They ignore the old man so he takes the Levite's concubine and sends her outside. The men raped and abused her through the night. When they were done with her, she went back to the old man's house and fell down at the door. The Levite opened the door in the morning and told her it was time to go, but there was no answer. The Levite puts her on his donkey and heads home. Upon reaching home, he cuts up his concubine into 12 pieces and sends them to all areas of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The people that saw it were shocked and looking for guidance.

In reaction to the 12 concubine pieces prompted all the Israelites from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink></jLink></jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink></jLink></jLink> (except the Benjamites) to gather in Mitpah, including 400,000 armed soldiers. They questioned the Levite how this had happened. The Levite tells an altered and incomplete story, that the Gibeah people wanted to kill him, not have sex with him. After the telling, all the people rose “as one man” and said they will bring the city of Gibeah to justice, by attacking it of course. The assembled Israelites demand the Benjamites to give up the evil people of Gibeah, but they prepare to guard Gibeah instead with 26,000 swordsmen and 700 highly accurate, left-handed stone slingers. The Israelites ask God who should attack first, to which God replies <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The first day of battle, 22,000 Israelites are slain. The Israelites ask God should they continue the battle, and God says yes. This results in 18,000 more Israelites being slain. All the remaining Israelites then went to Bethel, fasted, and made offerings. They asked God if they should attack again. God says yes, and this time He will deliver them into their hands. This time the Israelites actually used tactics to fight, setting up an ambush for Gibeah for when another line of soldiers lured the Benjamite warriors from their position. When the Benjamites had killed 30 Israelites, they claimed they were beating the Israelites as before. Gibeah was put to the sword and burned. The smoke signaled the counter-attack that would kill most of the Benjamite warriors. 600 Benjamites fled to the rock of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7417B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7417B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7417B' clickHandler>Rimmon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, while all the rest were killed. The Israelites pressed on and put to the sword all the other towns of the Benjamites.

The Israelites grieved that the Benjamites were nearly wiped out. The Israelites made a vow that anyone that didn't show up for this battle should be killed. They realized the 600 remaining Benjamites did not have wives left, so the tribe would die out without women. But they had made a vow that none of the Israelites at the battle should give their daughters to a Benjamite for a wife, or they would be cursed. Well, they realized the people of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink></jLink></jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink></jLink></jLink> had not attended the battle, so they had to be killed. The Israelites decided and carried out a plan to kill everyone but the virgins from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink></jLink></jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and marry the virgins to the Benjamites. But there were only 400 virgins, so 200 Benjamites remained without wives. They let the 200 spouse-less Benjamites ambush some dancing women during a festival to God in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink></jLink></jLink>. At that time, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> had no king so everyone did as they saw fit.

In the days of the judges, Elimelch and his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> (which means pleasant) moved from Bethlehem to a place in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink></jLink></jLink> with their two sons. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0458' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0458' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0458' clickHandler>Elimelech</jLink></jLink></jLink> dies. The sons got married to Moabites <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler>Orpah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink>. They all lived there for about 10 years, then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s sons died. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler>Orpah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> set out for Bethlehem. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler>Orpah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> to go back to their mothers' houses. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler>Orpah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> wept and said they'd follow <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> told them to go to their mothers' houses again, sighting that she was “too old to have another husband,” that it was impractical to wait for her to have a son and for that son to grow up, and that God's hand was against her. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler>Orpah</jLink></jLink></jLink> decides she will go back to her mother, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> stays with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> says to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6204' clickHandler>Orpah</jLink></jLink></jLink> is going back to her people and her gods and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> should do the same. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> claims she will stay with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> until death. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> arrive in Bethlehem. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5281' clickHandler>Naomi</jLink></jLink></jLink> says to call herself Mara (which means bitter) because of what God has done to her.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> finds a barley field where she can glean after the harvesters. The owner of that particular field was <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler>Boaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a prominent man from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0458' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0458' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0458' clickHandler>Elimelech</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s clan. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler>Boaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> stopped by the field and asked about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink>, to which the foreman replied she'd been steadily gleaning since morning. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1162G' clickHandler>Boaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> invites <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler>Ruth</jLink></jLink></jLink> to stay with his servant girls and continue to glean. He tells his men not to touch her. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7327' As a result, God promised to give <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> great wisdom and also riches and honor, making him greater than any other king.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> returned to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> and ruled the people with wisdom. He also established alliances with neighboring nations, including Hiram, the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who provided materials and workers for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s building projects.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> Prepares to Build the Temple: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> decides to build a Temple for the Lord in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Queen of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink></jLink></jLink> Visits <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink>: She hears about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s great wisdom and wealth. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Unfaithfulness: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of Judah, has become strong and wealthy. They will serve <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink></jLink></jLink>, but God will allow them to remain as a nation. This chapter highlights the consequences of turning away from God and the importance of humility.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Battle Against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>, becomes king of Judah. He faces <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of the northern tribes of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, in battle. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink> boldly declares that Judah is faithful to God and has the true worship of the Lord, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink></jLink></jLink> has led <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> into idolatry.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink> calls on the people of Judah to trust in God. During the battle, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink></jLink></jLink> tries to ambush <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s forces, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and his men cry out to God. God helps Judah defeat <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s army, and many of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s soldiers are killed. This victory reinforces the importance of faithfulness to God in times of conflict.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reforms: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the next king of Judah, who reigns after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, is described as a good king who does what is right in the eyes of the Lord. He removes foreign idols and restores the worship of God in Judah. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> also builds fortified cities and encourages the people to seek God.¶When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the Cushite king, attacks Judah with a vast army, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> calls upon God for help. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s faith leads to victory as God defeats <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s army. This chapter emphasizes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s commitment to God and the blessings that come from faith and obedience.

The Covenant with God: The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838M' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838M' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838M' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink></jLink></jLink> comes to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> and encourages him to remain faithful to God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> gathers the people of Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink></jLink></jLink> and leads them in a covenant to seek the Lord wholeheartedly. The people promise to worship God and turn away from idolatry.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> removes even more idols from the land and restores proper worship. The chapter highlights the importance of community commitment to God and the blessings that follow when a nation seeks the Lord.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Mistake: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> faces a new challenge from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who builds a fortress at Ramah to threaten Judah. Instead of trusting God as he did before, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> seeks help from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of Aram (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink></jLink></jLink>), offering him treasures from the Temple. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s decision leads to a temporary victory, but the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink></jLink></jLink> visits <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> and tells him that because he relied on the king of Aram instead of God, he will face wars in the future.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes angry with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink></jLink></jLink> and imprisons him. He also oppresses some of the people. This chapter serves as a warning against lack of faith and reliance on worldly solutions rather than trusting in God.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reign: After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king of Judah. He is a good king who follows the ways of his father, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> strengthens Judah, builds his military, and sends officials to teach the people about the Law of God. He emphasizes the importance of education and spiritual growth in the nation.¶Under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s leadership, Judah experiences peace and prosperity. This chapter highlights the impact of a king's faithfulness to God and the importance of teaching God's commandments to the people.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> forms an alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, by agreeing to marry his son to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s daughter. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> visits <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who wants to go to war against Ramoth-Gilead. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages seeking the advice of the prophets.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink> gathers 400 prophets, who all give him a positive message. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks for a true prophet of the Lord. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink> reluctantly calls for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler>Micaiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who prophesies that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink> will be defeated in battle. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink> disregards <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler>Micaiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s warning and goes to battle anyway, leading to his eventual death. This chapter emphasizes the importance of listening to God’s true messenger and not just those who provide comforting words.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reforms: After returning from battle, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> is confronted by the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058G' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who tells him that he has allied with the wicked and needs to correct his ways. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> then begins reforms to improve justice in Judah. He appoints judges in the land and instructs them to judge fairly and righteously, reminding them that they are accountable to God.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the people to trust in God during times of trouble. This chapter highlights the importance of justice and integrity in leadership and the need for leaders to guide their people in faithfulness to God.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Victory Over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammon</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of Judah, faces a serious threat from a coalition of enemies, including the Moabites and Ammonites. When these nations come to fight against Judah, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> seeks help from God and calls for a fast throughout Judah. The people gather at the Temple to pray for guidance.¶The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3166J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3166J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3166J' clickHandler>Jahaziel</jLink></jLink></jLink> speaks to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink>, assuring him that God will fight for them and they will not have to engage in battle. Encouraged by this message, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> leads the people in worship. The next day, they march towards the battlefield singing praises to God. When they arrive, they find that their enemies have turned on one another and are defeated. This chapter emphasizes the power of faith and prayer in overcoming challenges.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Wicked Reign: After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink></jLink></jLink> dies, his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king of Judah. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink></jLink></jLink> is described as an evil king who leads the people away from God. He kills his brothers to secure his throne and marries the daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, which leads him further into idolatry.¶During <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s reign, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink></jLink></jLink> rebels against Judah and establishes its own king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink></jLink></jLink> faces many troubles and is eventually struck with a painful disease. Despite his suffering, he does not turn to God for help. This chapter highlights the consequences of turning away from God and the impact of poor leadership.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Short Reign: Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s death, his youngest son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king. Like his father, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> is influenced by his mother, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and continues in the evil ways of the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>. His reign is short, lasting only one year.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> allies himself with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and goes to war against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of Aram. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274H' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> is injured in battle and returns to Jezreel to recover. This chapter shows how the influence of evil leaders can lead a nation astray.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Downfall: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the mother of Ahaziah, seizes power after her son’s death by killing the royal heirs. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a faithful priest, saves Joash, the infant son of Ahaziah, and hides him. When Joash is seven years old, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink></jLink></jLink> reveals him to the people and leads a coup against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶The Levites and people of Judah support Joash and proclaim him king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink></jLink></jLink> is captured and killed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink></jLink></jLink> then leads the people in renewing their covenant with God, promising to serve Him. This chapter highlights the importance of faithfulness to God and the restoration of rightful leadership.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reforms and Downfall: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink></jLink></jLink> reigns as a good king, following the guidance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He orders the repair of the Temple, collecting money from the people for this purpose. The repairs are completed, and the Temple is restored to its former glory.¶However, after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink></jLink></jLink> dies, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink></jLink></jLink> turns away from God and leads the people into idolatry. He has <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink></jLink></jLink>, killed for warning him against his evil ways. This chapter shows how the absence of righteous leadership can lead to spiritual decline.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reign and Defeat: After Joash’s death, his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> initially follows God but later seeks to strengthen his kingdom by hiring mercenaries from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> to fight against the Edomites. A prophet warns him that God does not want him to rely on these mercenaries.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> obeys and goes into battle with his own troops, defeating the Edomites. However, after the victory, he brings back the idols of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink></jLink></jLink> and begins to worship them. As a result, God sends a prophet to confront him, warning of impending judgment. This chapter highlights the dangers of mixing faith with idolatry.
