<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Prosperous Reign: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, also known as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838N' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838N' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838N' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, succeeds <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> as king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> is a good king who seeks God, and as long as he does, he is successful in his endeavors. He builds a strong military and fortifies <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> also engages in agricultural projects and is praised for his accomplishments. However, pride begins to grow in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s heart. He enters the Temple to burn incense, an act reserved for priests. The high priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838N' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838N' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838N' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink></jLink></jLink> confronts him, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes angry. As a result, God strikes him with leprosy, and he must live in isolation for the rest of his life. This chapter illustrates the dangers of pride and the importance of respecting God’s boundaries.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reign: After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s death, his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink></jLink></jLink> is described as a good king who follows God’s ways. He continues his father’s building projects and fortifies the city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink></jLink></jLink> also fights against the Ammonites, who pay tribute to him.¶During his reign, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink></jLink></jLink> builds a strong kingdom, but the people continue in their corrupt ways. This chapter emphasizes the importance of faithful leadership and the ongoing struggle against idolatry.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Wicked Reign: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king of Judah after his father, Jotham. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> is described as an evil king who does not follow the ways of God. He practices idolatry and even sacrifices his own son in a pagan ritual, following the detestable practices of the nations around him.¶During <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s reign, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> (the northern kingdom) attacks Judah and defeats him in battle. Many people from Judah are taken captive, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> is deeply troubled. Instead of turning to God for help, he seeks assistance from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8407' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8407' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8407' clickHandler>Tiglath-Pileser</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> pays him with treasures from the Temple, but <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink></jLink></jLink> eventually does not help him as he expected. This chapter highlights the consequences of turning away from God and trusting in foreign alliances.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reforms Begin: After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s death, his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king. He is a good king who follows the ways of God. He begins his reign by reopening and repairing the Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, which had been closed and neglected during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s rule.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> calls the priests and Levites to purify themselves and restore proper worship in the Temple. He organizes a great assembly to celebrate the Passover, inviting people from both Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. This chapter emphasizes the importance of worship, repentance, and returning to God after a period of neglect.

The Celebration of Passover: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> prepares to celebrate the Passover festival. He sends messengers throughout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> to invite everyone to join in the celebration. Many people from the northern tribes respond, despite some mocking the invitation.¶The celebration begins, and even though some participants are not ceremonially clean, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> prays for them, asking God to forgive them. The festival is a joyful occasion, and the people worship God together. This chapter demonstrates the power of unity in worship and the importance of remembering God’s deliverance.

The Organization of Worship: After the Passover, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> continues his reforms by organizing the priests and Levites to serve in the Temple. He establishes a system for the offerings and contributions from the people to support the priests.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> also encourages the people to bring their first fruits and tithes to the Temple, ensuring that the worship of God is prioritized. The chapter highlights the need for structure and organization in worship, as well as the importance of generosity in supporting God’s work.

The Threat from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink></jLink></jLink>: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5576' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5576' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5576' clickHandler>Sennacherib</jLink></jLink></jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink></jLink></jLink> invades Judah and threatens <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, aware of the impending attack, encourages the people to trust God. He strengthens the city’s defenses by repairing the walls and constructing towers.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> also reassures the people that God is on their side and that they should not fear the Assyrian army. The Assyrian king sends a message to intimidate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the people, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> prays for help. God responds by sending an angel to destroy the Assyrian army, leading to a great victory for Judah. This chapter emphasizes the importance of faith in God during times of crisis.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Repentance: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2396G' clickHandler>Hezekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, unlike his father, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes one of the most evil kings of Judah. He leads the nation into idolatry, including the worship of foreign gods and even sacrificing his own son.¶After being captured by the Assyrians, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink></jLink></jLink> humbles himself and prays to God for forgiveness while in captivity. God hears his prayers and restores him to his kingdom. Upon returning, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519H' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink></jLink></jLink> makes significant reforms, removing idols and restoring proper worship of God in Judah. This chapter illustrates the power of repentance and God’s mercy.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Reforms: After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king at the age of eight. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> follows the ways of his ancestor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> and seeks to restore true worship in Judah. During his reign, the Book of the Law is discovered in the Temple.¶Upon hearing the words of the Law, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> tears his clothes in grief because he realizes how far Judah has strayed from God’s commandments. He calls for reforms, removes idols, and renews the covenant with God, promising to follow His laws. This chapter highlights the importance of God’s Word and the impact it can have on a nation when it is taken seriously.

The Celebration of Passover Under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> organizes a grand celebration of the Passover, ensuring that it is celebrated properly in accordance with the Law. He provides offerings and encourages the people to participate fully in the festival.¶The Passover celebration is described as one of the greatest in the history of Judah, with many people attending. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s efforts to restore worship and observe God’s commands demonstrate his commitment to leading the nation back to God. This chapter emphasizes the joy and significance of worshiping God together as a community.

The Fall of Judah: The final days of the kingdom of Judah and its eventual fall. It begins with the reign of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who becomes king after his father's death. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> reigns for three months before he is taken captive by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Neco</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Neco</jLink></jLink></jLink> deposes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink></jLink></jLink> and places his brother Eliakim on the throne, renaming him <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink></jLink></jLink> reigns for eleven years, during which he does evil in the sight of the Lord. He ignores the warning of the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and oppresses the people. After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s death, his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink></jLink></jLink> becomes king but rules for only three months before being captured by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink></jLink></jLink> takes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink></jLink></jLink> and many other prominent citizens of Judah to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He then installs <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, another son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, as king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> also does evil and rebels against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>. After several years, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s rebellion leads to the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The city falls, the Temple is destroyed, and many people are taken into exile in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶The chapter concludes with a note of hope, as it mentions that after seventy years, God will allow the people to return to their homeland, fulfilling His promise to restore them. This chapter illustrates the consequences of disobedience to God and the importance of listening to His prophets.

In the 1st year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink></jLink></jLink> reign as king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, he proclaims that God gave him “all the kingdoms” on earth and has told him to build the Temple of God in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and that the Israelites should be allowed to go back and rebuild the Temple, and encouraged offerings for the Temple, fulfilling the prophesy of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The people gave offerings, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink></jLink></jLink> gave back the gold and solver taken from the Temple by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

This lists family lineage counts of the exiled Israelites that returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. There were some that returned that could not show proof of their lineage, so they were considered unclean. There were 42360 people, 7337 slaves, and 200 singers. They had 736 horses, 245 mules, 435 camels and 6,720 donkeys. Donations were taken for the repair work. Everyone went back to their original towns.

The head priest, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3442J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3442J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3442J' clickHandler>Jeshua</jLink></jLink></jLink>, built the altar of God. All of the sacrifices and burnt offerings were then done according to the Law. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the Levites oversaw the building of the new Temple. Upon laying the foundation, they gave praise to God that “His love to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>” is forever. The elders that had seen the former Temple wept at the new foundation.

Enemies of Judah worked to discourage the building of the Temple, and to frustrate the plans. This went on from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s reign through to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s reign of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The enemies solicited king Xerxes, and then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> to stop the rebuilding in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. To <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> they sent a letter saying that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> will revolt if it is rebuilt. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> agrees to halt their progress. No more progress was made until the 2nd year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s reign.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler>Haggai</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink></jLink></jLink> set about rebuilding the Temple. The governor questioned who gave them the authority to do so. The governor wrote a letter to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink></jLink></jLink> to ask him what to do, as the people of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judah</jLink></jLink></jLink> had replied that the permission came from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink></jLink></jLink> replies that the people of Judah should be allowed to rebuild the Temple, and furthermore the governor should supply anything that the people of Judah need for the Temple, including animals for the daily sacrifices, and anyone that obstructs the Temple construction should be put to death. The Temple was completed in the 6th year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s reign. The Temple was dedicated with the offering of 100 bulls, 200 rams, and 400 male lambs. Also, 12 male goats were provided as a sin offering, one for each tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The did everything according to the Law. The Jews celebrated Passover.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a teacher of the Law in the lineage of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink></jLink></jLink>, came to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> in the 7th year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> reign. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> gave <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> what he wanted, because God was with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> gave <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> a letter, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink> refers to himself as “king of kings”, with a decree that the exiled Israelites throughout the land should return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> with any offerings they can get to sacrifice to God, and that any excess valuables the Jews can keep, and that anything needed will be supplied by the royal treasury, and that the governors can't tax the Levites and priests, and that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> should appoint judges and make sure everyone knows and obeys the Law.

This lists family lineage counts of the exiled Israelites that returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> with Ezra. There were no Levites among them, so Ezra borrowed some Levites from nearby towns. Before setting out to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, Ezra conducted a fast and asked for God's help to keep them safe. They sum up the offerings they are taking, then they go to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. Upon getting there, they counted up the offerings, and found they had everything. They then sacrificed 12 bulls for all of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, 96 rams, 77 male lambs, and 12 male goats for a sin offering. All of these were burnt offerings.

The Jewish leaders tell Ezra that the people, including the Levites and the priests, have not kept themselves separate, so they have “mingled the holy race” with non-Jewish people. Ezra was appalled. In the evening, Ezra prays to God saying that God punished their forefathers for their sins, and now this Jewish remnant is sinning with intermarriage.

While <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> was praying, the Jews repented their interracial marriages. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7935L' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7935L' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7935L' clickHandler>Shecaniah</jLink></jLink></jLink> suggested they get rid of the foreign women and half-breed children. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> agreed with that plan, and then fasted. Every Jew was called to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> under the threat of losing their land. Once they were there, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> said their interracial marriages were sinful. The Jews agreed so that God's wrath would be turned away,and set up a plan to remove the foreign women. The foreign women were removed within 2 months. There is a list of those that were guilty of interracial marriage.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> asked about the Jews that survived the exile. He was told that the wall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> was broken and the gates were burned. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> wept, prayed and fasted several days. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> prays that God will give him favor in the presence of the king, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> was cupbearer to the king.

Nehemieh brought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, his wine. (It was the 20th year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s reign.) The king asked why was he sad. Nehemiah said he was sad because <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> was in ruins. The king asked what he wanted, to which Nehemiah replied that he wanted to go rebuild the city, and that he needed to granted safe passage as well as timber from the king's forest. The king agreed to this, sending an army and cavalry with him. The Horonite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the Ammonite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> were disturbed by this action. Nehemiah inspects the ruins and then convinces the Jews to start to repair and rebuild. The Ammonite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0694' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0694' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0694' clickHandler>Arab</jLink></jLink></jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1654' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1654' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1654' clickHandler>Geshem</jLink></jLink></jLink> questioned Nehemiah about this work, to which Nehemiah replied that God will make the work successful.

The repairs of the various wall sections and gates of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> were carried out by different families of the Jews.

The Horonite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the Ammonite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> mocked the Jews in their repair efforts. Nehemiah prays that God will not forgive and take revenge on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the Arabs, and the Ammonites were all angry at the progress being made in repairing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and conspired to stop it. Nehemiah arranged for half of the Jews to be armed and on guard while the other half continued with the repairs, and had those doing the repairs equipped with weapons.

Many Jews were having to borrow and mortgage from other Jews to survive the famine, and the lenders were charging usury. Nehemiah heard of this, got angry, and commanded that the lenders give back the usury and the properties belonging to the poorer Jews. During the 12 years of Nehemiah being governor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, he did not take any governor's pay.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1654' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1654' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1654' clickHandler>Geshem</jLink></jLink></jLink> send the same letter multiple times to draw Nehemiah away from the repairs, but Nehemiah refuses to go. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink> says that he will tell the king that Nehemiah is going to make <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> rebel, to which Nehemiah replies that such a story is a lie. The priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098S' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098S' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098S' clickHandler>Shemaiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> told Nehemiah to take refuge in the Temple because people were going to kill Nehemiah, but Nehemiah refuses. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098S' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098S' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098S' clickHandler>Shemaiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> had been hired by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink> to scare Nehemiah. Nehemiah prays that God remembers the sins of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5129H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5129H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5129H' clickHandler>Noadiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and the prophets that had tried to intimidate him. The wall repairs were completed in 52 days. Some people in Judah still had close relations with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> still tried to intimidate Nehemiah.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166G' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> assigned duties for administration of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The city was spacious compared to the number of people. The houses had not yet been rebuilt. This lists family lineage counts of the exiled Israelites that returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. There were some that returned that could not show proof of their lineage, so they were considered unclean. There were 42360 people, 7337 slaves, and 200 singers. They had 736 horses, 245 mules, 435 camels and 6,720 donkeys. Donations were taken for the repair work. Everyone went back to their original towns.

All the Jews assembled in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> to read them the Book of the Law. The Levites helped make the Law clear and give it meaning so people could understand it. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and the Levites told the people to stop grieving over the Law, because this was a sacred day. The people made booths of olive tree branches per the law for the Feast of Tabernacles in Leviticus 23. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink></jLink></jLink> read from the Law each of the 7 days of the Feast.

Later that month, the Israelites repented and fasted. They separated themselves from all foreigners. They spent a quarter of the day reading the Law, and a quarter of their day confessing their sins and in worship. The Levites pray to God, who is forgiving, gracious, merciful, compassionate, slow to anger, and abounding in love. The prayer briefly recounts the history of the Jews from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink> until then. A covenant with God was written and sealed by Levites and priests.

There is a list of the priests and Levites that sealed the written covenant. All the people take an oath to obey the Law, including bringing the firstborn sons and the firstborn of the cattle and flocks to the priests. Everything will be done according to the Law.

The Jewish leaders settled in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. From among the other people, volunteers, and one tenth of the people selected by lot were relocated to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. Everyone else lived in their original towns. Then there is a list of those that settled in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> and a brief description of the settlements outside of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

There is a list of the priests and Levites that returned to Judah with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Israelites purified themselves and held a big festival to dedicate the wall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. Large amounts of sacrifices were made, and the people rejoiced loudly. Men were appointed to administer the collection, storage, and distribution of the tithes.

After Nehemiah had returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink></jLink></jLink>, he requested a return visit to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The king granted this visit. Upon arrival, the Law was read, and the people heard how no Ammonite or Moabite should ever be allowed into the assembly of God, so they removed all people of foreign descent from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. Eliashib the priest had given <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink></jLink></jLink> a storeroom in the Temple, so Nehemiah purged that storeroom, had it purified, and then stored Temple goods there. Nehemiah also learned that the Levites and singers had been neglected in tithes, so he reestablished the tithes. Nehemiah also found that men of Judah were working on the Sabbath, and merchants were selling merchandise on the Sabbath. He rebuked them and stopped that sinful practice. Nehemiah also found some men of Judah had interracial marriages, and he rebuked and punished them for it.

In 3rd year of Xerxes rule of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, he held a banquet for the upper class. He had displayed his wealth for 180 days, and then he held the banquet for 7 days. Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink></jLink></jLink> gave a banquet at the same time for the women. On the last day of the banquet, Xerxes summoned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink></jLink></jLink> to display her beauty, but she refused to go. In order to prevent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s actions from becoming the impetus for women's rights, Xerxes has her deposed, and then sends out messengers proclaiming that the man is the ruler of the household.

Xerxes rounds up into his harem the most beautiful virgins throughout his kingdom for a contest where the one that best pleases the king will become the queen. A Jewish woman by the name of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> pleased the eunuch in charge of the harem, so he gave her a prominent position there. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> kept hid that she was Jewish. Each of the harem girls spent a year getting beauty treatments before meeting with Xerxes. Then each one would spend one night with Xerxes, and would not return unless he asked for her by name. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> turn came, Xerxes was attracted to her more than any of the other women, so he made her queen. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s uncle, revealed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> that two of the king's officials plotted to assassinate Xerxes. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> tells Xerxes giving credit to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the matter is investigated, and the officials are hanged.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink></jLink></jLink>, an Agagite, was elevated to a position of honor by Xerxes. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink> refused to pay <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink></jLink></jLink> honor. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink></jLink></jLink> is angered about this, and decided that he wanted to kill <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink> and all the Jews in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink></jLink></jLink> tells Xerxes that there is a people in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink> that do not obey the king, and that he wants to destroy them. Xerxes gives him permission to do so. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler>So</jLink></jLink></jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink></jLink></jLink> has scribes write letters from Xerxes to all of the provinces of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink> commanding them to kill all the Jews and plunder their belongings on the 13th day of the 1st month.

When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink> learned of the decree to kill the Jews, he donned sackcloth and morned outside the king's gate. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> send a messenger to find out why <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink> is upset. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink> reveals the plot to kill all of the Jews in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> to beg Xerxes for mercy for the Jews. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> was afraid to do this because anyone that came before the king without being summoned could be killed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink></jLink></jLink> says that she will not be protected from the genocide. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> tells the Jews to fast 3 days, then she will go before the king. The Jews followed her instructions.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink></jLink></jLink> appears before Xerxes, and he extends the gold scepter so that she will not be killed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler>Elihu</jLink></jLink></jLink> tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> to look up to the heavens above and consider how it is that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s sin could possibly affect God. He says any wicked or righteous behavior <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> does affects only those around <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>, not God. He says that God does not listen to arrogant, wicked men.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler>Elihu</jLink></jLink></jLink> claims that he is perfect in knowledge, so his words are true. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0453K' clickHandler>Elihu</jLink></jLink></jLink> says that God always rewards the righteous and punishes the wicked. He says the godless die young. He says God speaks to those who suffer to lead them down the righteous path. He warns <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> to stay away from evil. He then describes how awesome and powerful God is.
Elihu continues to describe how awesome and powerful God is. He then asks; how can any man dare to question God?

God comes out of a storm to talk to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>. God talks about how much more He knows than <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> does. God says the wicked are denied light and their upraised arms are broken. God continues to talk about how much more He knows than <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>. God asks if <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> knows where the light and the darkness reside. God asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> if he has ever seen the storehouses for snow and for hail, which God saves for times of battle and trouble. God asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> if he can move the constellations according to their seasons. God asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> if he can control the weather. God asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> who feeds the wild animals.

God talks about how much more He knows about animals than does <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>, such as how ostriches are stupid birds that are bad at parenting.

God asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> if he would try to correct God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> says that he is unworthy to talk to God. God confronts <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>, telling him to show his power if he thinks that he is as mighty as God. God tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> to consider the Behemoth, God's largest land creature.

God tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> to consider the Leviathan, God's largest sea creature. The Leviathan is said to be invulnerable and to breath fire.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> humbles himself due to God's awesomeness. He says that he had heard of God, but now he has actually seen God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> repents. God tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0464H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0464H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0464H' clickHandler>Eliphaz</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1085' clickHandler>Bildad</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6691' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6691' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6691' clickHandler>Zophar</jLink></jLink></jLink> that they were wrong, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> was right, and that they should make a sacrifice for their sin and have <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> pray for them. God blessed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> and made him twice as prosperous as he was before. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s brothers and sisters consoled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> for all the trouble God had brought on him. He had 7 sons and 3 daughters. His daughters were the most beautiful women in all the land. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink> then lived another 140 years.

The Two Ways: Contrasts the way of the righteous with the way of the wicked. It begins by describing the blessed person who does not follow the advice of the wicked, stand in the way of sinners, or sit in the company of mockers. Instead, this person delights in the law of the Lord and meditates on it day and night.¶The psalm compares the righteous to a tree planted by streams of water, which bears fruit in season and does not wither. In contrast, the wicked are likened to chaff that is blown away by the wind. Ultimately, the Lord watches over the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked leads to destruction.

The Reign of the Lord’s Anointed: Speaks of the rebellion of nations against God and His Anointed One, often interpreted as a reference to the Messiah. The psalm describes how kings and rulers conspire against the Lord, but God laughs at their plans. He declares that He has installed His king on Zion, His holy mountain. The psalm emphasizes the power and authority of God, urging the nations to submit to Him and serve the Lord with fear. It concludes with a warning that those who take refuge in God are blessed.

A Psalm of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> in Distress: A lament by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> when he fled from his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his fear as many enemies rise against him, saying there is no help for him in God. However, he affirms his trust in the Lord, who is a shield and provides him with strength. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> recalls how God answered his prayers and encourages himself to not be afraid. He concludes by asking God to save him from his enemies, emphasizing faith amid distress.

An Evening Psalm of Trust: A prayer of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> that reflects his trust in God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> calls upon God to answer him when he is in distress. He urges the people to turn from sin and trust in the Lord. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses confidence that God provides peace and joy, even in troubling times. He ends the psalm by stating that he will lie down and sleep in peace, knowing that God is with him. This psalm highlights the theme of seeking God’s peace in difficult times.

A Prayer for Guidance: In this psalm, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> cries out to God in the morning, seeking guidance and direction. He asks God to listen to his words and consider his groaning. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> contrasts himself with the wicked, stating that God does not take pleasure in evil and will not allow the arrogant to stand in His presence.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> seeks protection and guidance, asking God to lead him in righteousness because of his enemies. The psalm concludes with a prayer for joy and blessings upon those who take refuge in God, highlighting the importance of seeking God’s favor.

A Prayer for Mercy in Distress: Another lament by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> in which he pleads for God’s mercy during a time of deep distress. He asks God to not rebuke him in anger and pleads for healing from his physical and emotional suffering. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his sorrow, stating that he is weary from groaning. He calls on God to deliver him and acknowledges that the Lord has heard his cry. This psalm illustrates themes of repentance, desperation, and reliance on God’s mercy.

A Cry for Justice: A prayer of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> seeking justice against false accusations. In this psalm, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> calls upon the Lord to save him from his enemies. He proclaims his innocence, asking God to examine his heart and intentions. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses confidence that if he is indeed innocent, God will deliver him. He asks God to rise up against the wicked and to bring justice. The psalm concludes by affirming that God is a righteous judge who saves the upright in heart. This psalm emphasizes themes of justice, righteousness, and divine protection.

The Glory of God and Humanity: Begins with a declaration of God’s majesty and glory. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> praises God for His creation, stating that His name is glorious in all the earth. He marvels at the heavens, the moon, and the stars, reflecting on humanity's smallness in comparison to the vast universe.¶Despite this, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> acknowledges that God has made humans a little lower than the angels and crowned them with glory and honor. He emphasizes that God has given people authority over the works of His hands, such as animals and nature. This psalm highlights the dignity of humanity and the responsibility given by God.

Praise for God’s Justice: Begins with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> praising the Lord for His wonderful deeds and justice. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> recounts how God has defeated his enemies and established His throne for judgment. He expresses confidence that God will uphold justice and protect the oppressed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the people to trust in the Lord, who does not forget the needy. The psalm concludes with a reminder that God will judge the nations and be a refuge for those who seek Him. This psalm emphasizes themes of thanksgiving, justice, and God’s faithfulness.

The Plea for Justice: Cry for Justice: The speaker petitions God for justice against those who oppress and harm the innocent.¶Faith in God’s Righteousness: The ode emphasizes the belief that God will ultimately deliver justice and protect the faithful.¶Desire for Restoration: The speaker expresses hope for the restoration of righteousness in the world.¶Key themes include justice, oppression, and restoration.
