The Psalm recalls how God delivered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink> and gave them laws to follow. However, it also highlights how the people have turned away from God and neglected His commands. The Psalmist urges the people to listen to God and follow His ways, promising that if they do, God will bless them with abundance. The Psalm concludes with a reminder of God's desire to provide for His people.

God is depicted as a judge who presides over a divine council. The Psalmist addresses the unjust rulers and judges of the earth, accusing them of failing to defend the weak and the poor. God calls these rulers to account for their actions, reminding them that they are not above Him and will face judgment. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of justice and righteousness in leadership. It concludes with a plea for God to rise up and judge the earth, as He is the ultimate authority.

A plea for help against a coalition of enemy nations that have conspired to destroy <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist names several nations, including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6429' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6429' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6429' clickHandler>Philistia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, which have united against God's people. He calls for God to act against these enemies, asking Him to make them like chaff in the wind. The Psalm emphasizes the need for God to defend His people and to show the nations that He is the true God. It concludes with a request for God's name to be known and glorified among the nations.

Expresses a deep love for the Temple and the presence of God. The Psalmist longs to dwell in God's house, describing it as a place of joy and blessing. He compares the happiness of those who live in God's presence to the hardships of those who are away from Him. The Psalm emphasizes that even the smallest parts of the Temple, like the sparrows and swallows that find a home there, are blessed. The Psalmist prays for strength and favor from God, affirming that trusting in Him leads to true joy.

The Psalmist reflects on God's past kindness and restoration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He begins by recalling how God has forgiven and restored His people after their sins. The Psalmist asks God to revive His people again and to show His mercy. He desires peace and reconciliation between God and His people. The Psalm emphasizes the hope that righteousness and peace will meet, and it concludes with a prayer for God's continued guidance and blessing.

A prayer of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> asking for God's mercy and help. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> acknowledges his own vulnerability and need for God’s protection. He calls upon God, recognizing Him as gracious, compassionate, and slow to anger. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks God to listen to his prayer and to answer him. He expresses his trust in God and his desire to serve Him. The Psalm highlights the uniqueness of God and His power to save. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes with a plea for God to show him a sign of His goodness so that others may see and be encouraged.

A celebration of Zion, which represents <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist begins by declaring that the city of Zion is the foundation of God’s presence on earth. He describes how God loves Zion more than any other place. The Psalm mentions how people from other nations, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, will acknowledge Zion as a significant place. The Psalm emphasizes that those born in Zion are blessed and that God will write their names as citizens of this holy city. It concludes with a joyful proclamation that all who find their home in Zion will rejoice in God.

A lament attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1968G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1968G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1968G' clickHandler>Heman</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a servant of the Lord. It is one of the darkest Psalms, expressing deep sorrow and despair. The Psalmist cries out to God for help, feeling overwhelmed by troubles and surrounded by darkness. He describes his suffering and how he feels abandoned by friends and family. The Psalmist repeatedly asks God to hear his prayer and to rescue him from death. Despite his pain, he acknowledges God’s power. However, the Psalm ends without a resolution, leaving the reader with a sense of unresolved anguish, highlighting the depth of human suffering.

A reflection on God’s covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> and His faithfulness. The Psalmist begins by praising God for His steadfast love and faithfulness. He recounts how God made a covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, promising that his descendants would rule forever. However, the Psalmist expresses confusion and sorrow because it seems that God has forgotten His promises during times of trouble. The Psalm mentions how the enemies of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> have attacked and how the throne of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> seems to be in jeopardy. It concludes with a plea for God to remember His covenant and restore His people, affirming God’s greatness and faithfulness.

Attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>, reflects on the eternal nature of God compared to the fleeting nature of human life. The Psalmist acknowledges that God is everlasting, while humans are temporary and frail. He expresses the brevity of life, stating that even a lifespan of seventy or eighty years is filled with trouble. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of seeking God’s wisdom and guidance, as life is short and uncertain. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks God to show His mercy and to establish the work of our hands, seeking a sense of meaning and purpose in life.

A declaration of trust in God’s protection. The Psalmist describes how those who dwell in the secret place of the Most High will find safety and refuge in God. It speaks of God as a shield and fortress, promising deliverance from dangers such as deadly diseases and attacks from enemies. The Psalm emphasizes that God will command His angels to protect those who trust in Him. The Psalmist expresses confidence that God will answer prayers and be with His people in times of trouble, concluding with a promise of long life and salvation for those who love Him.

A song of praise for the Sabbath, celebrating God’s goodness and faithfulness. The Psalmist begins by expressing gratitude for God’s love and wonderful deeds. It highlights the joy of worshiping God and proclaiming His greatness. The Psalm contrasts the fate of the wicked with the flourishing of the righteous, comparing them to palm trees and cedars of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The righteous will bear fruit even in old age, staying fresh and green. The Psalm concludes with a declaration that God is upright and that He is a rock, emphasizing His enduring nature.

A short but powerful proclamation of God’s kingship. The Psalmist declares that the Lord reigns, clothed in majesty and strength. It emphasizes that God’s throne is established forever, and He is mightier than the chaotic waters. The Psalm celebrates God’s sovereign authority over creation and reassures the faithful that God is in control amid chaos. It concludes by affirming the holiness of God, which is a source of stability and strength for His people.

A plea for justice against the wicked. The Psalmist asks God to rise up and judge those who oppress the righteous, particularly the arrogant and violent. He expresses confidence that God sees the injustices happening in the world. The Psalmist reminds the people that God disciplines those He loves and emphasizes the importance of trusting in Him during times of trouble. The Psalm concludes with the assurance that God will not forsake His people and will provide them with comfort and support.

A call to worship and praise God. The Psalmist invites the people to sing joyfully and shout to the Lord, acknowledging Him as the rock of salvation. It emphasizes the importance of coming before God with thanksgiving and singing praises. The Psalm recalls that God is the Creator of the earth and the sea, and it highlights His greatness over all gods. However, it also serves as a warning, reminding the people not to harden their hearts as the Israelites did at Meribah, where they doubted God’s provision. The Psalm concludes with a declaration that those who hear God’s voice should listen and not rebel against Him.

A celebration of God’s reign and an invitation for all nations to worship Him. The Psalmist calls for a new song of praise to be sung to the Lord, proclaiming His glory among the nations. It emphasizes that God is the Creator and that He will judge the world with righteousness. The Psalm mentions the joy of the earth and the heavens rejoicing because of God’s justice. It encourages people to declare God’s wondrous deeds and to recognize that He is worthy of praise. The Psalm concludes with a call for all creation to be glad in the Lord’s coming judgment.

Proclaims the Lord’s sovereignty and power. The Psalmist begins by declaring that the Lord reigns, and the earth should rejoice. The Psalm describes God’s majesty, mentioning that dark clouds surround Him, symbolizing His mysterious power. It speaks of the Lord’s judgment against the wicked, who will be consumed by His fire. The Psalm emphasizes that those who love the Lord should hate evil, as He protects the righteous. The conclusion celebrates the joy and deliverance that God brings to His people, affirming that His reign will last forever.

A joyful song of praise for God’s salvation. The Psalmist begins by singing a new song to the Lord for His wonderful deeds and salvation. It recalls how God has revealed His righteousness to the nations and remembers His faithfulness to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalm emphasizes that all creation should rejoice, including the rivers, hills, and fields. The imagery of nature celebrating God’s greatness highlights that His salvation is for everyone. The Psalm concludes with a call for the whole world to shout for joy before the Lord as He comes to judge the earth.

Celebrates the holiness and sovereignty of God. The Psalmist declares that the Lord reigns, sitting enthroned between the cherubim, which symbolizes His presence. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of worshiping God and acknowledges His greatness among the nations. It recalls the holiness of God and how He answered the prayers of His people, specifically mentioning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink></jLink></jLink> as examples of those who called upon Him. The Psalm concludes with a call to worship the Lord in His holiness and to praise His name.

A joyful call to worship the Lord. The Psalmist invites all the earth to shout for joy and serve the Lord with gladness. It emphasizes entering God’s gates with thanksgiving and His courts with praise. The Psalm acknowledges that the Lord is God and that He made us, affirming that we are His people. It celebrates God’s goodness, love, and faithfulness, assuring that His mercy endures forever. This Psalm serves as a reminder of the joy that comes from worshiping and serving God.

A personal pledge by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> to live righteously and lead his household according to God’s ways. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins by declaring his commitment to singing of God’s love and justice. He expresses a desire to walk blamelessly and to avoid wickedness. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of integrity and the rejection of deceitful practices. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> also mentions that he will not tolerate evil in his presence and will seek to surround himself with faithful people. The Psalm concludes with a commitment to destroy the wicked from the land, highlighting a desire for justice and righteousness.

A prayer of distress from someone who is suffering. The Psalmist cries out to God, expressing feelings of loneliness, weakness, and despair. He describes his days as fleeting and compares himself to a withered plant. Despite his troubles, the Psalmist remembers God’s eternal nature and faithfulness. He acknowledges that God will rise up and have compassion on Zion and that the time for restoration will come. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of hope and trust in God, affirming that God’s name will endure forever and that He will not forget His people.

A beautiful hymn of praise attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist begins by calling on his soul to bless the Lord and not forget His benefits. He lists the many ways God has blessed His people, including forgiving sins, healing diseases, and redeeming life from destruction. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes God’s compassion and love, comparing it to a father’s kindness toward his children. The Psalm highlights God’s mercy and grace, stating that He does not treat us as our sins deserve. It also reflects on the eternal nature of God’s love and faithfulness, reassuring that His righteousness extends to future generations.

A majestic celebration of God’s creation. The Psalmist praises God for His greatness and how He has made the heavens and the earth. It describes God’s majesty and how He is clothed with splendor and majesty. The Psalm recounts the creation of the world, including the establishment of the seas, mountains, and various forms of life, such as animals and plants. The Psalmist marvels at God’s provision for all living creatures, emphasizing that they depend on Him for sustenance. It concludes with a call to praise God, recognizing His power and the wonder of His works.

Recounts the history of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> and God’s faithfulness to His people. The Psalmist begins by encouraging the people to give thanks to the Lord and to proclaim His wonderful deeds. It recalls the covenant God made with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and how He fulfilled His promises to their descendants. The Psalm highlights significant events in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s history, including the Israelites’ time in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>, their deliverance through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and their journey to the Promised Land. It emphasizes that God’s presence guided His people and that He protected them throughout their trials. The Psalm concludes by celebrating God’s eternal faithfulness to His covenant.

A historical reflection on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s unfaithfulness to God. The Psalmist begins by praising the Lord for His goodness and enduring love. However, it quickly recounts the failures of the Israelites, who repeatedly turned away from God despite His miracles and mercy. The Psalm mentions key events, such as the Israelites’ rebellion in the wilderness, their idolatry with the golden calf, and their complaints against God. Despite their disobedience, the Psalm emphasizes God’s compassion and willingness to forgive. It concludes with a plea for God to save His people and gather them from the nations, acknowledging their need for redemption.

A song of thanksgiving for God’s deliverance. The Psalmist invites the redeemed of the Lord to give thanks and recounts various situations in which people found themselves in trouble. It describes how God delivered those who were lost, hungry, and in distress. The Psalm highlights different groups of people, including those who wandered in the desert, those in prison, and those who faced storms at sea. In each case, when they cried out to God for help, He rescued them. The Psalm emphasizes God’s steadfast love and faithfulness and encourages the people to reflect on His goodness and to share their testimonies of His deliverance.

A declaration of confidence in God’s power and a call to praise. It combines themes from earlier Psalms, expressing a desire to sing praises to God with all of one’s heart. The Psalmist proclaims God’s steadfast love and faithfulness and calls for God to help in battle against enemies. It mentions the Lord’s support for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> and expresses trust that God will give victory. The Psalm emphasizes that, with God’s help, the people can overcome their challenges.

A lament that expresses <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s distress and plea for justice against his enemies. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> cries out to God, asking for help against a deceitful enemy who has falsely accused him and is seeking to harm him. He describes the cruel actions of his enemies and prays for God to turn their evil against them. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks God to replace the enemy with a righteous person and pleads for justice. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of relying on God during times of trouble and seeking His intervention against wrongdoing.

A royal Psalm attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, which speaks of the Messiah. It begins with the Lord speaking to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s Lord, indicating a divine relationship. The Psalm proclaims that the Messiah will sit at God’s right hand and reign. It speaks of the Messiah’s victory over enemies and His establishment of a kingdom of righteousness. The Psalm also mentions the priestly role of the Messiah, comparing Him to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a priest-king from the Old Testament. This Psalm emphasizes the authority and power of the Messiah, affirming His role in God’s divine plan.

A hymn of praise that celebrates the greatness of God. The Psalmist begins by declaring that he will praise the Lord with his whole heart in the assembly of the upright. He recounts the works of the Lord, emphasizing His deeds that are full of majesty and splendor. The Psalm highlights God's faithfulness, His provision for His people, and the establishment of His covenant. The Psalmist marvels at God's wisdom and how He has provided guidance for those who fear Him. It concludes with a powerful statement that the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and those who practice it will have good understanding.

A celebration of the blessings that come to those who fear the Lord and delight in His commands. The Psalmist describes the characteristics of a righteous person, noting that they are generous, compassionate, and just. Their families are blessed, and they will not be shaken by adversity, as they trust in the Lord. The Psalm emphasizes that the righteous will be remembered forever and will have no fear of bad news because their hearts are steadfast. It concludes with a contrast, stating that the wicked will see the prosperity of the righteous and be angry, but their plans will come to nothing.

A call to praise the Lord, highlighting His greatness and care for the humble. The Psalmist begins by urging everyone to praise the Lord, from the rising of the sun to its setting. It emphasizes that God is exalted above all nations and glory is above the heavens. The Psalm highlights God's compassion as He looks down on the poor and needy, lifting them from the dust and ash heap to dignify them. It celebrates the fact that God provides for the barren woman, giving her joy through children. The Psalm concludes with a joyful proclamation to praise the Lord.

Recounts the powerful presence of God among His people, particularly during the Exodus from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist describes how the sea fled and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink></jLink></jLink> River turned back when the Israelites crossed into the Promised Land. These miraculous events demonstrate God's sovereignty over creation. The Psalm emphasizes that when the Israelites left <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>, they were led by God, who made the mountains and hills tremble. The Psalm concludes with a rhetorical question, asking what makes the earth tremble, suggesting that it is God’s presence that brings about such awe.

Contrasts the living God with useless idols made by human hands. The Psalmist begins by declaring that glory should go to the Lord and not to humans. It discusses the futility of idols, stating that they cannot speak, see, hear, or smell. The Psalm emphasizes that those who make and trust in idols will become like them. It encourages the people of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> to trust in the Lord, who is their help and shield. The Psalm concludes with a blessing for the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink></jLink></jLink>, affirming that God will bless those who fear Him, both small and great.

A personal expression of gratitude and love for God’s deliverance. The Psalmist begins by stating that he loves the Lord because He hears his prayers. He recounts how he was in distress and called on the Lord, who saved him from death and sorrow. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of faithfulness in response to God’s mercy. The Psalmist vows to offer thanksgiving and fulfill his promises to the Lord in the presence of His people. It concludes with a recognition of the preciousness of life and the importance of serving God.

The shortest Psalm and is a call for all nations to praise the Lord. The Psalmist urges all peoples to extol the Lord for His steadfast love and faithfulness. It emphasizes that God's love is great and that His truth endures forever. This Psalm highlights the universality of God's love and the call for all nations to recognize and worship Him.

A joyful declaration of God’s goodness and mercy. The Psalmist begins by giving thanks to the Lord, stating that His love endures forever. It recounts how God has been a source of strength and help during difficult times. The Psalm mentions the rejection of the stone that has become the cornerstone, symbolizing God’s salvific plan. It emphasizes the importance of trusting the Lord rather than relying on human strength. The Psalmist rejoices that God has saved him and invites others to join in celebrating the Lord’s victory. It concludes with a proclamation of blessings in the name of the Lord.

The longest chapter in the Bible and is an acrostic poem focused on the beauty and importance of God’s Word, the Law. Divided into 22 sections, each corresponding to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet, it emphasizes themes of love for God’s commandments and the desire to follow His teachings. The Psalmist expresses deep devotion to God's laws, stating that they bring wisdom, joy, and guidance. Throughout the Psalm, the writer reflects on the struggles of life, including persecution and hardship, but remains committed to God’s instructions. The Psalm concludes with a plea for God to seek out the lost and to help the writer keep His statutes.

A lament that expresses distress and a longing for peace. The Psalmist cries out to the Lord from a place of suffering and deceit, mentioning how he lives among those who are hostile and untrustworthy. He calls for God to deliver him from lying lips and deceitful tongues. The Psalmist reflects on the difficulties of living in a world filled with conflict and war, feeling like a stranger in a foreign land. The Psalm concludes with a lament about the consequences of living with those who do not seek peace.

A song of trust and assurance in God’s protection. The Psalmist begins by looking to the mountains and asking where help comes from. He declares that his help comes from the Lord, the Creator of heaven and earth. The Psalm emphasizes that God will not let the believer stumble and that He watches over them day and night. It reassures that God will protect from all harm and will guard the person’s life. The Psalmist concludes with the promise that God will watch over the believer’s coming and going, now and forever.

A joyful expression of the Psalmist’s love for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist rejoices at the invitation to go to the house of the Lord. He describes <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> as a city of peace, where the tribes of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> gather to worship. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of unity and peace within the city and calls for prayers for its well-being. The Psalmist encourages the reader to seek peace and prosper in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, recognizing it as a special place where God dwells.

A plea for mercy from God. The Psalmist lifts their eyes to the Lord, comparing their situation to a servant looking to their master for help. The Psalmist expresses feelings of contempt and disdain from those who are proud and arrogant. It conveys a deep sense of longing for God’s mercy and favor in the face of oppression. The Psalm concludes with a prayer for God to have compassion on His people.

A declaration of gratitude for God’s deliverance. The Psalmist begins by acknowledging that if it had not been for the Lord’s help, the people of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> would have been overwhelmed by their enemies. They recount how the waters would have swept them away, but God intervened. The Psalmist expresses confidence in God as their protector and acknowledges that their help comes from the Lord, who made heaven and earth. The Psalm concludes with praise for God’s protection and deliverance.

A song of confidence in God’s protection over Zion. The Psalmist describes how those who trust in the Lord are like Mount Zion, which cannot be shaken. It emphasizes the security and stability that comes from trusting in God. The Psalmist acknowledges that while the wicked may be present, they will not prevail against the righteous. It concludes with a prayer for peace and blessings upon the righteous and a warning against the ways of the wicked.

A song of joy and remembrance of God’s restoration. The Psalmist recalls the time when the Lord restored the fortunes of Zion, and the people rejoiced. It reflects on the joy of returning from captivity and the laughter that filled their mouths. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of remembering God’s faithfulness and how those who sow in tears will reap with joy. It concludes with a promise that God will continue to bring restoration and harvest joy from the struggles endured.

A reflection on the importance of God’s blessing in all endeavors. The Psalmist begins by stating that unless the Lord builds a house, the builders work in vain. This emphasizes that success in any project, especially in building a home or a city, requires God’s involvement. The Psalm also highlights that God grants sleep to His beloved, indicating that trust in Him brings peace and rest. Furthermore, the Psalm discusses children as a heritage from the Lord, describing them as arrows in the hands of a warrior. The Psalm concludes by stating that blessed is the man who has a full quiver of children, implying that having children is a great blessing from God.

A song that celebrates the blessings of those who fear the Lord. The Psalmist begins by stating that those who walk in God’s ways will be blessed. It describes the blessings that come to the individual, their family, and their work. The Psalm paints a picture of a prosperous household, illustrating the joy of seeing children and grandchildren. It also mentions Zion, emphasizing that those who fear the Lord will see the prosperity of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> throughout their lives. The Psalm concludes with a prayer for peace upon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, reflecting the hope for well-being in the community.

A lament that reflects on the suffering of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist acknowledges that the people have faced oppression and hardship from their youth. It recalls how the enemies have tried to harm <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, but God has not allowed them to prevail. The Psalmist emphasizes that although the enemies have cut at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> like a farmer cutting weeds, they will not succeed in their plans. It concludes with a call for God’s blessing upon those who love Zion, reinforcing the idea that God protects His people from their adversaries.

A heartfelt cry for mercy and forgiveness. The Psalmist begins with a deep sense of despair, crying out to the Lord from the depths. He acknowledges his sins and the need for God’s forgiveness. The Psalm emphasizes that if the Lord kept a record of sins, no one could stand before Him. However, the Psalmist expresses hope in God’s unfailing love and redemption. He calls on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> to put their hope in the Lord, for with Him is full redemption. The Psalm concludes with the assurance that God will redeem His people from all their sins.

A humble expression of trust in God. The Psalmist, who is attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, describes how he has calmed and quieted his soul, much like a weaned child with its mother. This imagery emphasizes peace and contentment in God. The Psalmist rejects pride and great ambitions, choosing instead to trust in the Lord. He calls on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> to hope in the Lord from now and forever, indicating a call for collective trust in God’s care and provision.

Recalls God’s covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the significance of Zion. The Psalmist remembers how <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> made a vow to find a dwelling place for the Lord. It recounts God’s promise to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> that his descendants would endure forever. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of Zion as God’s chosen dwelling place, where God will bless His people. It concludes with a promise that God will bless the city and its inhabitants, reaffirming the significance of His presence among His people.

Celebrates the beauty of unity among God’s people. The Psalmist begins by declaring how good and pleasant it is when brothers dwell together in harmony. He uses the imagery of precious oil poured on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s beard, representing anointing, and the dew of Mount Hermon, which symbolizes refreshment. This Psalm emphasizes that unity among God’s people brings blessings and life. It concludes with the affirmation that God commands His blessings where there is unity.

A call to worship and blessing for the servants of the Lord. The Psalmist invites all who serve in the house of the Lord to bless Him. It emphasizes the importance of lifting hands in worship and praising the Lord at night. The Psalm concludes with a blessing for the people, stating that the Lord, who made heaven and earth, will bless them. This Psalm highlights the joy and duty of worshiping God.

A hymn of praise that celebrates the greatness of God. The Psalmist begins by calling on the servants of the Lord to praise His name, emphasizing that the Lord is good and His name is pleasant. It recounts God's mighty acts, such as His creation of the heavens and the earth, and His deliverance of the Israelites from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalm contrasts the power of the living God with the uselessness of idols made by human hands. It concludes with a call for the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and all who fear the Lord to bless Him.

A psalm of thanksgiving that repeatedly emphasizes God's steadfast love. The Psalmist recounts God's acts of creation, including the heavens, the earth, and the great lights. It also highlights God's deliverance of the Israelites from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>, His guidance through the Red Sea, and His defeat of powerful kings, such as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5511' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5511' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5511' clickHandler>Sihon</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5747' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5747' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5747' clickHandler>Og</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The refrain "for his steadfast love endures forever" is repeated throughout the Psalm, emphasizing God's unwavering love and faithfulness. The Psalm concludes with a call for the people to give thanks to the God of heaven, whose love endures forever.

A lament that expresses the sorrow and longing of the Israelites during their exile in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The Psalmist describes how the people wept by the rivers of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, unable to sing the Lord's songs in a foreign land. They were taunted by their captors, who demanded that they entertain them with songs from Zion. The Psalm expresses a desire for vengeance against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and a commitment to never forget <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. It concludes with a prayer for the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink> and a declaration of love for Zion.

A song of thanksgiving and praise to God. The Psalmist, who is attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, declares that he will give thanks to the Lord with his whole heart and will sing praises to Him. The Psalm emphasizes God's faithfulness and steadfast love, stating that He has exalted His name and word above all things. It also acknowledges that even when the Psalmist was in distress, God answered him and made him bold and strong. The Psalm concludes with a confident declaration that the Lord will fulfill His purpose for the Psalmist and that His love endures forever.

A profound meditation on God's omniscience and omnipresence. The Psalmist, attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, acknowledges that God knows everything about him, from his thoughts to his actions. The Psalm emphasizes that God's knowledge and presence are inescapable, as He is present in the highest heavens and the deepest depths. It also reflects on God's creation of the Psalmist, stating that he was fearfully and wonderfully made. The Psalm concludes with a plea for God to search the Psalmist's heart and lead him in the way everlasting.

A prayer for protection from evil and violent people. The Psalmist, who is attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, cries out to the Lord for help, asking Him to deliver him from the hands of the wicked. The Psalm describes the malicious plans and sharp tongues of the evildoers, who seek to trap and destroy the Psalmist. It expresses confidence that the Lord will defend the cause of the afflicted and maintain the right of the poor. The Psalm concludes with a declaration that the righteous will give thanks to God's name and dwell in His presence.

A prayer for help and guidance. The Psalmist, attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, begins by calling on the Lord to hear his voice and to set a guard over his mouth. He expresses a desire to avoid the temptations of the wicked and to be corrected by the righteous. The Psalm emphasizes the importance of maintaining a right relationship with God and avoiding the snares of the evil. It concludes with a plea for the Lord to protect the Psalmist from the traps of the wicked and to lead him in the way of righteousness.

A prayer of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> in a time of distress. The Psalmist, who is identified as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, cries out to the Lord, expressing his need for help and protection. He describes how he is overwhelmed by his troubles and feels alone, with no one to care for his soul. The Psalm emphasizes the Psalmist's trust in God, stating that the Lord is his refuge and portion in the land of the living. It concludes with a request for the Lord to bring the Psalmist out of prison, so that he may praise God's name.

A heartfelt prayer of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> in a time of distress. The Psalmist begins by pleading for God to hear his prayer and to answer him quickly. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses feelings of despair and loneliness, stating that his spirit is faint and his heart is overwhelmed. He recalls the days of old when he meditated on God’s works and wonders. The Psalm emphasizes the need for guidance, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks God to lead him in the right path. He expresses trust in God’s faithfulness and pleads for deliverance from his enemies. The Psalm concludes with a request for God to revive his spirit and help him fulfill His will.

A song of praise and a plea for God’s help in battle. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins by blessing the Lord, who is his rock and teaches him how to fight. He acknowledges that human life is fragile, comparing it to a breath or a shadow. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink> prays for God to rescue him from foreign enemies and expresses confidence in God’s power. He describes the blessings of having a strong nation and a peaceful home. The Psalm emphasizes the joy of having children and families that thrive. It concludes with a declaration of blessing upon the people of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, highlighting the goodness of God.

A majestic acrostic Psalm attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink></jLink></jLink>, praising God for His greatness and goodness. The Psalmist begins by declaring his intention to exalt God and bless His name forever. It emphasizes God's mighty acts, compassion, and faithfulness. The Psalmist describes how all creation praises God and reflects on His abundant goodness. It highlights that God is near to all who call on Him and fulfills the desires of those who fear Him. The Psalm concludes with the affirmation that all who love God will be blessed, and it calls for perpetual praise of His holy name.

A call to praise the Lord and trust in Him. The Psalmist begins by encouraging all people to praise the Lord for as long as they live. He warns against trusting in human leaders, stating that they cannot provide true help or salvation. The Psalm emphasizes that God is the Creator who upholds justice, feeds the hungry, and sets prisoners free. It highlights God's love for the righteous and care for the foreigner and the widow. The Psalm concludes with a declaration that the Lord reigns forever and that He will be a refuge for His people.

A celebration of God's power and care for His creation. The Psalmist begins by proclaiming that praising God is good and delightful. It describes God's healing power, as He binds up the brokenhearted and counts the stars. The Psalm emphasizes God's sovereignty over nature, mentioning how He sends snow and rain. It also highlights God’s special relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, stating that He does not treat other nations in the same way. The Psalm concludes with a call to praise the Lord, recognizing His greatness and goodness.

A cosmic hymn that calls all of creation to praise the Lord. The Psalmist begins by inviting the heavens, the angels, and the sun, moon, and stars to praise God. It emphasizes that God created everything and set their boundaries. The Psalm extends the call to praise to the earth, mountains, hills, and all living creatures. It also includes praise from kings, princes, and all people. The Psalm concludes by stating that God's name is exalted above all, and it highlights the honor and praise that belong to His people.

A joyful song celebrating God’s people and their victories. The Psalmist calls for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> to rejoice in their Maker and to sing a new song in the assembly of the faithful. It emphasizes the beauty of worship and the joy of God’s people. The Psalm highlights the power given to God's people to execute judgment on their enemies. It describes the honor of being called to serve God and the joy found in His presence. The Psalm concludes with a call for all people to praise the Lord with instruments and dance.

The final Psalm and a triumphant call to praise God. The Psalmist begins by declaring that praise should be given to God in His sanctuary and in the heavens. It emphasizes praising God for His mighty deeds and greatness. The Psalm instructs the use of various instruments, including trumpets, harps, lyres, tambourines, strings, and cymbals, to express praise. It concludes with a universal call for everything that has breath to praise the Lord, underscoring the importance of worship in all creation.

Introduces the purpose of the book: to impart wisdom, discipline, and understanding. The chapter begins by calling out to the simple, urging them to seek wisdom. The fear of the Lord is described as the beginning of knowledge, while fools despise wisdom and instruction. The chapter warns against the temptation of joining with sinners who entice others to commit wrongdoing. It emphasizes that those who ignore wisdom will face consequences, using the metaphor of wisdom calling out in the streets. The chapter concludes with the promise that those who listen to wisdom will be secure and free from fear.

Encourages the pursuit of wisdom and the benefits that come from seeking it. The chapter starts by urging the reader to accept and treasure wisdom, seeking it like hidden treasure. It promises that understanding will come to those who search for wisdom earnestly. The chapter describes how wisdom protects and guides a person, leading them away from evil paths and the company of wicked people. It highlights the importance of making wise choices, which will keep one on the right path. The chapter concludes by stating that the wise will dwell in safety and that righteousness will lead to a good life.

Emphasizes trust in the Lord and the importance of following His guidance. The chapter begins with a call to remember God’s commands and to keep His teachings in one’s heart. It assures that trusting in the Lord will bring health and prosperity. The famous verse instructs to "acknowledge Him in all your ways," promising that He will make your paths straight. The chapter also warns against the pride of relying on one’s own understanding. It encourages discipline and correction from the Lord, comparing it to a father’s love for his children. The chapter concludes with the blessings that come from wisdom and the advantages of living a righteous life.

A father’s instruction to his children, emphasizing the importance of wisdom and understanding. The chapter begins with an appeal to listen to the teachings of the father and to embrace wisdom. It encourages the reader to hold on to wisdom as a precious possession. The chapter describes wisdom as a protective guide that leads one away from wickedness. It contrasts the path of the righteous, which shines brighter, against the way of the wicked, which is dark and leads to destruction. The chapter concludes with a reminder to guard one’s heart, as it is the source of life, and to keep one’s eyes focused on wisdom.

Warns against the dangers of adultery and the seduction of an unfaithful woman. The chapter begins by encouraging the reader to pay attention to wisdom and to avoid the allure of the seductive words of others. It describes the consequences of engaging in an affair, emphasizing that it leads to regret and destruction. The father warns that giving in to temptation can lead to a loss of honor and wealth. The chapter advises the importance of being faithful in marriage and enjoying the spouse’s love. It concludes with a reminder that God sees all actions, and one cannot escape the consequences of foolish choices.

Provides various warnings and practical advice. The chapter begins by cautioning against being trapped by impulsive promises, especially regarding loans. It advises the reader to be diligent like an ant, which works hard to prepare for the future. The chapter also warns against the wicked person who causes trouble and strife. It identifies six things that the Lord hates, including pride, lying, and stirring up conflict. The chapter advises staying away from immoral women and emphasizes the importance of fidelity. It concludes by stressing that wandering away from wisdom can lead to destruction and suffering.

Tells a story illustrating the dangers of falling into temptation, particularly through the seduction of an immoral woman. The father advises his son to keep his teachings close and to remember them. The chapter describes a young man who is easily led astray by the alluring words and actions of a seductive woman. It highlights how she entices him with flattery and promises of pleasure. The chapter warns that giving in to such temptation can lead to death and destruction. It concludes with a strong warning to be vigilant and to avoid the traps of temptation.

Presents a personification of wisdom as a woman calling out to people. Wisdom claims to be present at the beginning of creation, with God, and highlights her role in bringing order to the world. She cries out in the streets, inviting everyone to listen and learn from her. Wisdom speaks about the value of her teachings, stating that they are more precious than silver and gold. The chapter contrasts the benefits of following wisdom with the consequences of ignoring her. It emphasizes that those who find wisdom find life and favor from the Lord. The chapter concludes with a strong affirmation that wisdom is essential for a fulfilling life.

Contrasts wisdom with foolishness. Wisdom is depicted as a woman who has built her house and prepared a feast, inviting the simple and those who lack understanding to come and eat. She encourages people to leave their foolish ways and gain understanding. In contrast, the chapter describes the call of folly, personified as a loud and seductive woman, who leads people astray. The chapter emphasizes the importance of revering the Lord, stating that the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom. It concludes by highlighting that knowledge of the Holy One is understanding and warns that those who reject wisdom lead to their own destruction.

Introduces a series of wise sayings and contrasts between the righteous and the wicked. The chapter begins with a comparison between wise children and foolish children, highlighting the joy that wise children bring to their parents. It discusses the benefits of righteousness, which brings life and blessings, compared to the consequences of wickedness, which leads to shame and disaster. The chapter includes practical advice about speech, wealth, and work. It emphasizes the importance of integrity and honesty, stating that the mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, while the mouth of the wicked conceals violence. The chapter concludes with the affirmation that the righteous will endure, while the wicked will face judgment.

Continues with contrasting themes between the upright and the wicked. The chapter begins by emphasizing the importance of honesty in business and the consequences of deceitful practices. It highlights that pride leads to disgrace, while humility brings wisdom. The chapter discusses the benefits of righteousness, stating that it delivers from death and leads to life. It also emphasizes the importance of generosity, stating that those who give to the poor will not lack. The chapter warns that the wicked will perish, but the righteous will flourish. It concludes with the idea that the fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and those who win souls are wise.

Provides various pieces of wisdom, emphasizing the importance of knowledge and understanding. It begins by stating that those who love discipline love knowledge. The chapter contrasts the plans of the righteous with the schemes of the wicked, indicating that God will protect the righteous. It discusses the value of hard work and diligence, stating that the hand of the diligent will rule. The chapter highlights the importance of truthful speech, noting that the words of the wicked are deceitful. It concludes by stating that anxiety weighs down the heart, but a kind word brings joy.

Focuses on the consequences of choices and the importance of wisdom. The chapter begins by stating that a wise son hears his father’s instruction, while a scoffer does not listen. It emphasizes the value of wise choices that lead to life and prosperity. The chapter warns against the dangers of laziness, stating that it leads to poverty. It also highlights the importance of integrity in relationships and business dealings. The chapter concludes with the idea that hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.

Continues with wise sayings that emphasize the contrast between wisdom and foolishness. The chapter begins by stating that wise women build their homes, while foolish women tear them down. It discusses the importance of reverence for the Lord, stating that it leads to life and safety. The chapter contrasts the laughter of fools with the seriousness of the wise. It also highlights the value of understanding in making sound decisions. The chapter concludes by emphasizing that a heart at peace gives life to the body, while envy rots the bones.

Offers insights into communication and relationships. The chapter begins by stating that a gentle answer turns away anger, while a harsh word stirs up wrath. It emphasizes the importance of wise speech and the impact it has on others. The chapter contrasts the responses of the wise with those of fools. It discusses the value of listening to instruction and the importance of seeking understanding. The chapter highlights the joy that comes from a cheerful heart and the danger of a broken spirit. It concludes with the idea that the path of the righteous leads to life, while the way of the wicked leads to destruction.

Emphasizes the sovereignty of God in human plans and actions. The chapter begins by stating that while people may plan their ways, it is the Lord who directs their steps. It discusses the importance of committing one’s plans to the Lord for success. The chapter highlights that pride leads to destruction, while humility results in honor. It also discusses the importance of honest speech and the impact of wise counsel. The Proverbs in this chapter emphasize that a king’s favor is like a messenger of life, and righteousness is crucial for good leadership. The chapter concludes by reaffirming that wisdom brings understanding and that it is better to be humble than to be proud.

Offers insights into relationships and the value of wisdom. The chapter begins by stating that a dry piece of bread with peace is better than a feast with strife. It emphasizes the importance of good relationships, particularly among family and friends. The chapter highlights the value of a wise servant over a foolish son, indicating that wisdom is more valuable than wealth. It warns against quarreling and foolish speech, which can lead to conflict. The chapter also acknowledges the importance of a good reputation. It concludes by stating that a cheerful heart is good medicine, while a crushed spirit dries up the bones.

Speaks about the power of words and the importance of understanding. The chapter begins by highlighting that a person who isolates themselves seeks their own desires and rejects all sound judgment. It emphasizes the significance of wise counsel and warns that the tongue has the power of life and death. The chapter discusses the importance of listening before speaking and the value of a good name over riches. It also mentions that a friend loves at all times, while a brother is born for adversity. The chapter concludes with the idea that wealth can create a stronghold, but it is the Lord who ultimately provides.

Focuses on the consequences of one's choices and actions. The chapter begins by stating that a person without knowledge is not good and that it is better to be poor than to be a liar. It emphasizes the importance of wisdom and understanding over material wealth. The chapter discusses the consequences of folly, stating that it brings destruction. It highlights the need for discipline and correction, indicating that foolishness leads to suffering. The chapter also notes that kindness to the poor is like lending to the Lord, who will repay. It concludes by stating that a person who listens to advice will gain wisdom.

Addresses various aspects of life, including honesty and integrity. The chapter begins by discussing the dangers of excessive drinking and how it leads to foolishness. It emphasizes the importance of honesty in business and how the Lord weighs the motives of the heart. The chapter also highlights the value of a good reputation and the importance of seeking counsel. It discusses the significance of hard work and diligence, stating that plans succeed through counsel. The chapter concludes with the affirmation that even young people are known by their actions, and integrity is essential for a good life.

Emphasizes the importance of righteousness and justice in leadership. The chapter begins by stating that the king's heart is in the hands of the Lord, and He can direct it as He wishes. It highlights the value of seeking righteousness over wealth and the consequences of wickedness. The chapter discusses the importance of wise decisions and the danger of pride. It also emphasizes that better to live in a corner of the roof than with a contentious wife. The chapter concludes by stating that righteousness leads to life and that those who seek the Lord will find Him.

Begins with the statement that a good name is more desirable than great riches. It emphasizes the importance of character and reputation. The chapter discusses the value of wisdom in raising children, stating that training them in the right way will lead them to not depart from it. It warns against the consequences of poor choices and the impact of bad company. The chapter also highlights the importance of generosity and warns about the dangers of borrowing. It concludes with the idea that the words of the wise should be applied to life for success.

Provides practical advice for various situations in life. The chapter begins by instructing readers to be mindful of their appetite when dining with a ruler. It warns against desiring the food of those who are greedy. The chapter emphasizes the importance of discipline and correction, stating that a son who is loved is disciplined. It encourages the pursuit of wisdom and understanding, indicating that they are more valuable than material wealth. The chapter also discusses the importance of avoiding drunkenness and the dangers of excessive pleasure. It concludes with a reminder to keep one’s heart focused on wisdom and to teach children the way of righteousness.

Emphasizes the importance of wisdom, understanding, and good judgment. The chapter begins by warning against envying evil people and desiring their ways. It highlights that wisdom is essential for building a strong home. The Proverbs encourage seeking knowledge and understanding rather than relying on brute strength. The chapter discusses the importance of counsel and suggests that wise people will face challenges but will ultimately prevail. It concludes with the idea that those who are righteous have a firm foundation, while the wicked will face consequences for their actions.

Presents additional wise sayings, many of which are attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The chapter begins by stating that it is the glory of God to conceal things, and it is the glory of kings to search them out. It emphasizes the need for humility and restraint, especially in the presence of powerful people. The chapter discusses the importance of appropriate speech and how a gentle answer can turn away anger. It advises against excessive boasting and emphasizes that a wise person knows when to keep silent. The chapter concludes with practical advice on relationships and the importance of maintaining a good reputation.

Focuses on the characteristics of fools and the consequences of foolish behavior. The chapter begins by stating that honor is not fitting for a fool. It warns against answering a fool according to his folly, which can lead to unnecessary conflict. The chapter emphasizes that a fool may bring destruction upon himself through his actions. It also discusses the importance of wisdom and the dangers of laziness. The chapter concludes with a humorous but serious warning about the nature of fools, stating that they are like a dog returning to its vomit, illustrating the foolishness of repeating mistakes.

Offers practical advice about relationships, friendship, and self-reflection. The chapter begins with a reminder not to boast about tomorrow, as the future is uncertain. It emphasizes the value of good friends, stating that a friend loves at all times and is there for you in times of trouble. The chapter warns about the dangers of excessive praise and the importance of honest feedback. It highlights the significance of iron sharpening iron, indicating that friendships can help improve character and wisdom. The chapter concludes with the idea that one’s heart should be set on the Lord, and it is better to be humble than prideful.

Discusses the themes of righteousness, justice, and the consequences of one’s actions. The chapter begins by stating that the wicked flee even when no one pursues them, while the righteous are bold as a lion. It emphasizes the importance of keeping God’s laws and the blessings that come from obedience. The chapter warns against corruption and injustice, stating that those who are greedy and exploit others will ultimately face ruin. It also highlights the importance of honesty and integrity in business dealings. The chapter concludes with the idea that he who conceals his sins will not prosper, but whoever confesses and renounces them will find mercy.

Addresses leadership and the behavior of people. The chapter begins by stating that a person who remains stiff-necked after many rebukes will suddenly be destroyed without remedy. It emphasizes the importance of good leadership and the necessity for rulers to be just and fair. The chapter discusses the consequences of poor leadership on the people and the value of wisdom in governance. It also highlights that when the righteous thrive, the city rejoices, but sin leads to chaos. The chapter concludes with the reminder that the fear of the Lord is critical for a successful and harmonious community.

Presents the sayings of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0094' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0094' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0094' clickHandler>Agur</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a wise man who expresses humility and recognizes his limitations. The chapter begins with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0094' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0094' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0094' clickHandler>Agur</jLink></jLink></jLink> admitting that he is not as wise as he should be and that he seeks understanding from God. He describes the greatness of God and reflects on the wonders of creation. The chapter includes a list of things that are unexplainable, such as the way of an eagle in the sky. It warns against arrogance and emphasizes the importance of being humble. The chapter concludes with a prayer for moderation, asking God to provide just enough to live without falling into temptation or poverty.

Describes the "wife of noble character." The chapter begins with advice from King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3927' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3927' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3927' clickHandler>Lemuel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who shares wisdom learned from his mother. It warns against excessive drinking and the consequences it can bring. The description of the noble wife highlights her strength, wisdom, and diligence. She is portrayed as someone who manages her household well, works hard, and provides for her family. The chapter celebrates her character and contributions, emphasizing that a woman who fears the Lord is to be praised. It concludes with a call to honor and appreciate such women for their valuable role in society.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> talks about how life is meaningless. He says that generations come and go, and men are forgotten, meanwhile the earth remains forever and continues through its natural cycles. He claims that there is nothing new under the sun, and that what is thought to be new turns out to be old. He has devoted himself to the study of wisdom only to find it to be meaningless, like chasing the wind. More knowledge only brings more grief.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> decided to turn to pleasures. He accomplished many projects, amassed great wealth, and experienced any physical pleasure that he desired. However, he ultimately found this to be meaningless as well. He reasons that wisdom is better than foolishness, just like light is better than darkness, but finds them both to be meaningless in the end. Both the fool and the wise man will die and be forgotten. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler>So</jLink></jLink></jLink> he began to hate his possessions and the products of his hard toil, because these things would just be inherited by his successor, who had not worked for them and may be a fool. The best a man can do is enjoy his food, his drink, and his work. God grants wisdom, knowledge, and happiness to those that please Him, but to the sinner He makes them toil for wealth just to hand it over to someone God chooses.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> says that there is a proper time for everything. God has given man the ability to think about eternity, yet they can't fathom all that God has done. The best a man can do while they live is to be happy and do good. The enjoyment of food, drink, and work is available to all and is a gift of God. What God does endures forever without change so that men will revere him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> saw wickedness in the places of judgement and justice, so he thought to himself God would judge both the righteous and the wicked according to His timing. Man can see that they share the same fate as animals; death. Nobody knows if a man's spirit goes up to Heaven. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler>So</jLink></jLink></jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes that the best a man can do is enjoy his work, because he doesn't know what happens after he dies.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> sees how people are oppressed and claims that the dead are better off, and the yet-to-be-born are even better than the dead because they haven't seen evil. All achievement comes from envy. It's better to be poor and peaceful than rich in meaningless pursuits. A lonely man's work is meaningless and risky. Even if a prisoner or poor man becomes a king, he will be forgotten in time, making his achievement meaningless.

Listen to God and sacrifice with a purpose. Speak with few words. Respect any vows you make to God or else God will destroy the work of your hands. Fear God. Don't be surprised to see injustice and oppression when there is a corrupt king. Whoever loves money will never be satisfied with what they have. Possessions only please the eyes. A poor worker sleeps better than a wealthy man. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink></jLink></jLink> has seen hoarded wealth harm its owner, and seen collected wealth lost, leaving no inheritance. A man is born with nothing and dies with nothing, making the product of his labor meaningless. The best a man can do is enjoy his food, his drink, and his work in the few days God has given him.
