The promise of grace is guaranteed to all of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s literal and figurative offspring through faith in God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink> had faith that God would fulfill His promise: to make <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink> a father, despite his being old and his wife being through menopause already. This faith was credited as righteousness by God. God will grant the same righteousness to those who believe in the sacrifice of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

By faith we have peace with God, being in grace with God through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. We glory in suffering, which builds endurance, character, and hope. This is God's love, in our hearts through the Holy Spirit. Some may die for a good man, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> died for us while we were sinners. We have been reconciled with God through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' blood and resurrection. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler>Sin</jLink></jLink></jLink> and death entered the world through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and everybody died because they all sinned. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler>Sin</jLink></jLink></jLink> existed before the Law, but nobody was accountable for it. Still, people died up to the time of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink> without breaking God's commandments. Just like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s sin condemned all people to die, God's gift of grace through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> has resulted in justification and eternal life being available to all people. God made the Law to make transgression increase, so that grace could increase even more.

However, we should not continue sinning to increase grace. We are dead to sin, as through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> we have died and now live a new life. Our old self was crucified with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, so we are free from sin. Just as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> now lives for God, so do we. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5471' clickHandler>So</jLink></jLink></jLink> do not obey your natural, evil desires, but rather become completely an instrument of righteousness. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5512B' clickHandler>Sin</jLink></jLink></jLink> is not your master, because you are under grace, not the Law. Do not continue to sin because of your status of grace, rather become a slave to righteousness, obeying God. Your prior wickedness gained you nothing but your present shame. Now your obedience will lead to holiness and eternal life. The wages of sin is death, but God's gift is eternal life through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

The Law is only binding while someone lives. A widow is not guilty of adultery by marrying another man. You have died through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and now belong to Him. Before, our sinful lusts were aroused by the Law. Now through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' death, we are free from the Law to serve in the Spirit. If not for the Law, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> would not have recognized sin. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> was alive before knowing the Law, but upon knowing it, sin in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> made him transgress the Law and thereby condemned him to death. However, the Law is not sinful itself, but rather it is holy, righteous, and good. The Law was used to bring about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s death and to make sin completely sinful. The Law is spiritual, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> is flesh and is sold to sin. Although <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> delights in God's Law and desires to obey it, he still sins because good does not dwell in him. Instead, sin living in him makes him continue to sin. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> is a prisoner to sin, and is thankful to be delivered from its consequences through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

There is no condemnation if you are in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, because though <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> the law of the Spirit frees you from the Law of sin and death. The Law was powerless because of sin, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' sin offering condemned sin in flesh to make us (who live by the Spirit, not the flesh) fully righteous. Those in the realm of flesh cannot obey God's Law or please God, but those of the Spirit seek with their minds what God desires. You are not in the realm of flesh if God's Spirit is in you. If you do not have <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' Spirit, you do not belong to Him. Though your body will die due to sin, God will resurrect your mortal body because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' Spirit is in you. We have an obligation to put fleshly sins to death by the Spirit in order to live. The children of God have received the Spirit, as we have received it. As God's children, we are heirs, and we may share is <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' suffering in order to share in His glory. Our sufferings now will be nothing compared to our future glory. All of creation has been yearning for the children of God to be revealed to be liberated from decay. We have patient hope for the time when our bodies will be redeemed. The Spirit intercedes for us in our prayers, aligning them with the will of God. God works everything for the good of His loving Elect. The Elect were predestined to be like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and accordingly called by God to be glorified. God is for us, and the resurrected <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> intercedes for us at God's right hand, so that nobody can condemn us. Though we may suffer all types of hardships, persecution, and disasters, we will never be separated from God's love through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> wishes that he could be cursed in order to save all of the Jewish people, who ultimately contained the human lineage of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. God's word has not failed with the Jews. Not all people in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s lineage are considered God's children, as we see in the case of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink></jLink></jLink> versus Ishmael. Only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink></jLink></jLink> received the promise. Similarly, God's policy of Election can be seen in His favoring of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink></jLink></jLink> instead of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink></jLink></jLink> from before their births. Is God unjust? No, God will give mercy and compassion on people according to His will. Human effort is irrelevant. God has the right to condemn or bless whoever He wants. What if God is being patient with His wrath on those who He has chosen to condemn in order to demonstrate His glory to His Elect? The Elect consist of both Jews and Gentiles, but only a small remnant of Jews will be saved from God's wrath. That is because the Gentiles obtained righteousness by faith, but the Jews have pursued righteousness through obedience to the Law. The Jews missed their goal of righteousness through works, stumbling on the stone which God placed in front of them.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> desires that all of the Jews get saved, because they are zealous for God. Yet the Jews do not know God's righteousness, so they pursued their own. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> culminated the Law, making righteousness available to all believers. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink> writes of righteousness, saying that people who obey the Law will live. However, righteousness by faith is available to all who believe in their hearts in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' resurrection and profess that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is Lord. That is why it was so important to spread this Gospel; so that people could hear it and believe. Yet despite the Gospel reaching the ends of the world, most of the Jews have kept to their tradition of obstinate disbelief, just as it was prophesied.

God did not reject all of the Jews. Some of them He predestined to be included in the Elect, preserving a remnant by grace. God prevented the rest of the Jews from understanding His grace through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> hopes that the Salvation of the Gentiles will arouse at least some of the Jews by envy to the same Salvation. The Gentiles should not be arrogant in their present position, because, just like God did not spare the unfaithful Jews, God will not tolerate the Gentiles acting irreverently either. Jews who change into believers will be granted Salvation. The Jews are just being hardened until all of the necessary Gentiles have been saved. At that time, all of the Jews will then be saved because of God's promised love to their patriarchs. The Jews are just disobedient now to obtain the same mercy which has been given to the Gentile. God is smart beyond human comprehension.

Be a living sacrifice for God in body and mind in order to discern God's perfect will. Realize that we should all play different roles in the collective body of God's organization according to the individual gifts with which we have been graced. Be sincere in love, devoted in love and respect for each other, full of zeal for God, joyous in hope, patient of afflictions, and faithful prayers. Give to needy believers. Live in harmony with each other regardless of status. Do what is right. Bless your persecutors. Do not curse anyone or repay evil for evil, for you should let God handle vengeance. In fact, overcome evil by doing good to those who hate you.

Do whatever authorities tell you, because God has established all authority figures. Otherwise God will judge you. Authorities will not harm anyone for doing good, but they will readily punish wrongdoers. Pay the taxes, revenue, respect, and honor which is due to authorities. Pay all debts. Love your neighbor, and you will fulfill the Law. Understand that Salvation is coming very soon, so behave righteously through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

Accept people into the faith even if they are not able to fully understand it, and do so without debating their understanding. Only God is their judge, and God is on their side. It does not matter what someone thinks is the right way to honor God, as long as they remain true to their belief. We all live and die for God, so do not be judgemental of a fellow believer. Each of us will stand before God's judgement for ourselves. Nothing is really unclean, but if someone regards something as unclean then it is unclean for them. Be aware of such regards from your fellow believers and alter your behavior as to not offend them and, by that offense, drive them away from belief. The Kingdom of God is about righteousness, peace, and joy, so do what is necessary to be harmonious with your fellow believers. This will please God and keep the peace. Keep your own particular views of right and wrong between you and God, and do not be a hypocrite.

We should overlook each others' faults and try to please one another. The Scriptures teach us endurance and encouragement, and may we all have that same attitude, like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, thereby bringing glory to God. Accept each other like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> accepts you. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' glory and mercy shines through the Jews to the Gentiles. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> knows that the Roman believers are full of goodness and knowledge of God, but he wanted to remind them of these things because, by grace, his duty is to spread the Gospel to the Gentiles so that they will be a sanctified offering to God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> is happy that he has lead Gentiles to belief by his teaching of the Gospel and his miraculous signs. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> tries to go places where the Gospel has not yet been heard, which is why he has delayed going to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink></jLink></jLink>. Now that the Gospel has been spread completely in this region, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> will go to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4681' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4681' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4681' clickHandler>Spain</jLink></jLink></jLink>, stopping by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink></jLink></jLink> for a visit on the way, but first <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> will go through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> to distribute financial aid to poor Jews; material aid which was owed to them by the Gentiles of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler>Achaia</jLink></jLink></jLink> for sharing in the Jews' spiritual blessings. Pray to God to keep <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> safe from unbelievers in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3063N' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3063N' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3063N' clickHandler>Judea</jLink></jLink></jLink> so that he can visit the Romans with joy. God be with you all.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> is sending them <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5402' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5402' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5402' clickHandler>Phoebe</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who is a deacon. They should aid her as necessary, because she has helped many people. Greet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink></jLink></jLink> and Aquilla, who risked their lives for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the Gentile churches. Greet a list of various men and women who have been good friends and hard workers for God. Greet each other with a holy kiss. Stay away from people who cause divisions or who teach contrary to what you have learned. They are selfishly deceptive. Your obedience is renowned, but stay away from evil. God will soon destroy Satan. May the grace of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> be with you. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3066' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3066' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3066' clickHandler>Lucius</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink></jLink></jLink>, Sosipater, Terius (the one to whom <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> is dictating this letter), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050I' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2037' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2037' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2037' clickHandler>Erastus</jLink></jLink></jLink> all say hello. For the revelation of the true meanings of the old prophesies, and for the Salvation of the Gentiles through faith, glory be to God forever.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins with greetings and thanks for the Corinthians. He addresses the problem of divisions within the Church, with some claiming to follow <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink>, others following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and others claiming to follow Cephas (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink>) or even Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that Christ is not divided and that he was not sent to baptize but to preach the Gospel. He stresses the importance of the cross and how God’s wisdom is different from human wisdom.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> explains that when he came to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink></jLink></jLink>, he did not use lofty words or wisdom but preached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> crucified. He relied on the Holy Spirit to reveal God’s truth. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> contrasts the wisdom of God with the wisdom of the world, explaining that the spiritual truths are understood only through the Spirit. He emphasizes that believers have the mind of Christ, allowing them to discern spiritual matters.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> continues addressing the divisions. He compares the Church to a field and a building, stating that he and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink></jLink></jLink> are merely servants of God. He stresses that the foundation of the Church is <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ, and each person must build on this foundation with care. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> warns that their work will be tested, and only what is built on Christ will last. He reminds the Corinthians that they are God’s temple and that God’s Spirit dwells among them.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses the role of apostles and emphasizes humility. He states that they are servants of Christ and stewards of God’s mysteries. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> urges the Corinthians not to judge prematurely and reminds them that they will be judged by the Lord. He uses himself and his fellow apostles as examples of humility, suffering, and dedication to the Gospel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his desire to visit <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink></jLink></jLink> and correct the arrogance of some members.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses a serious case of immorality within the Church, where a man is sleeping with his father’s wife. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> is shocked that the Church has not acted against this sin. He instructs them to expel the immoral person to protect the integrity of the Church. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> explains that a little yeast represents the corrupting influence of sin, urging them to be pure and remove sin from their community.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses issues of lawsuits among believers. He questions why they would take their disputes to secular courts instead of resolving them within the Church. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> reminds them that believers will judge the world and even angels, urging them to seek wise counsel from fellow believers. He also warns against sexual immorality, explaining that the body is a temple of the Holy Spirit and that Christians should honor God with their bodies.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses marriage and singleness. He begins by stating that it is good for a man not to marry, but for those who cannot control their desires, marriage is better than burning with passion. He provides guidance for married couples, encouraging them to fulfill their marital duties and not to separate unless mutually agreed upon for prayer. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> also addresses widows and advises them that it is good to remain single, but they can remarry if they desire, as long as it is in the Lord. The key message is to live according to one’s calling, whether married or single.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the issue of food offered to idols. He acknowledges that idols are not real gods and that believers have knowledge that there is only one God. However, he emphasizes that knowledge should be used with love. Some believers may be weak in faith and could be led astray if others eat food offered to idols. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the Corinthians to avoid causing others to stumble in their faith by being sensitive to their consciences.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> defends his rights as an apostle. He explains that he has the right to receive support from the Church, like other apostles such as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> and John, but he chooses to work and not rely on them financially to avoid hindering the Gospel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses how he adapts his approach to reach different people, becoming "all things to all people" in order to save some. He emphasizes the importance of self-discipline in running the race of faith.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> warns the Corinthians against idolatry. He uses the example of the Israelites who, despite experiencing God’s miracles, fell into sin. He reminds them that they should not take part in idol worship or participate in meals offered to idols, as this could lead them away from God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that believers cannot drink from the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons at the same time. He encourages them to do everything for God’s glory and to avoid causing others to stumble.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses issues related to worship and the Lord’s Supper. He discusses the proper conduct during worship, including the importance of head coverings for women, which signifies authority and respect. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> then moves on to the Lord’s Supper, explaining that it should be taken seriously. He criticizes the Corinthians for their divisions and for not properly honoring the body of Christ during the meal. He instructs them to examine themselves before partaking in the communion to avoid judgment.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses spiritual gifts. He explains that the Holy Spirit gives different gifts to believers for the common good of the Church. He lists various gifts, including wisdom, knowledge, faith, healing, miracles, prophecy, and speaking in tongues. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> uses the analogy of the body to illustrate that just as a body has many parts that work together, the Church functions as one body with Christ as the head. Each believer has a unique role, and all gifts are important.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes the importance of love. He explains that no matter how gifted someone may be, without love, those gifts are meaningless. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> describes love as patient, kind, not envious or boastful, and not easily angered. He highlights that love never fails and is more important than any spiritual gift. This chapter is often referred to as the "Love Chapter," focusing on the enduring nature of love.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> provides guidelines for the use of spiritual gifts, especially speaking in tongues and prophecy. He encourages believers to desire spiritual gifts that build up the Church. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> explains that prophecy is more beneficial than speaking in tongues because it edifies the Church. He urges orderly worship, stating that everything should be done decently and in order. He emphasizes the importance of understanding in worship, so everyone can be edified.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses doubts about the resurrection. He begins by reminding the Corinthians of the Gospel he preached, which includes Christ’s death, burial, and resurrection. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> provides evidence of the resurrection, mentioning that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the twelve disciples, and over five hundred others. He explains that if there is no resurrection, then faith is in vain. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> teaches that the resurrection is essential for eternal life, and he describes the transformation that will happen at the resurrection of the dead.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes the letter with practical instructions and greetings. He discusses the collection for the saints in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> and encourages the Corinthians to contribute. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> plans to visit them after traveling through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He encourages them to stand firm in their faith, to be courageous, and to do everything in love. He sends greetings from various believers, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and ends with a call for the grace of the Lord <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ to be with them.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> opens by expressing gratitude for God's comfort and the comfort he has received during his troubles. He emphasizes that the afflictions he faces are for the benefit of the Corinthians so that they may also experience comfort. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> mentions his struggles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, where he felt overwhelmed and despaired of life itself. He reassures the Corinthians that he is not writing to condemn them but to encourage them. He also speaks of the joy he felt when he learned about their response to his previous letter, which brought him relief. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes the chapter by affirming his commitment to preaching the Gospel and his integrity in his dealings with them.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses the need for forgiveness and reconciliation. He expresses his concern about a person who caused pain within the Church, possibly referring to someone who sinned against the community. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> urges the Corinthians to forgive and comfort this person so that he does not become overwhelmed by sorrow. He emphasizes that forgiveness is essential, as it reflects the forgiveness they have received from Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> also mentions his anxiety about the Corinthians and how he was relieved to find joy in their obedience and love.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> contrasts the old covenant, given through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>, with the new covenant established by Christ. He explains that the old covenant brought death because it was written on stone tablets, while the new covenant brings life. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> highlights that believers are ministers of this new covenant, empowered by the Holy Spirit. He uses the analogy of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>’ glory when he came down from Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Sinai</jLink></jLink></jLink>, stating that the glory of the old covenant fades away compared to the surpassing glory of the new covenant. This new covenant allows believers to have direct access to God, reflecting His glory.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses the treasure of the Gospel, which is held in jars of clay—referring to the fragility of human beings. He explains that despite facing hardships, persecutions, and challenges, he does not lose heart because he relies on the power of God. He emphasizes that the suffering he endures is temporary and produces eternal glory. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the Corinthians to focus on what is unseen, rather than what is seen, as the unseen is eternal. He expresses confidence in the resurrection, knowing that even though his earthly body may fade, he has a heavenly dwelling prepared by God.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> continues discussing the hope of eternal life. He explains that if our earthly bodies are destroyed, we have a building from God, an eternal house in heaven. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his desire to be clothed with this heavenly dwelling. He emphasizes that believers are ambassadors for Christ, called to share the message of reconciliation with God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> explains that God made Christ, who had no sin, to be sin for us, so that in Him, we might become the righteousness of God. He urges the Corinthians to accept this gift of reconciliation and to live in a way that reflects their new identity in Christ.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes the importance of not receiving God’s grace in vain. He highlights the hardships that he and his companions have faced in their ministry, including beatings, imprisonments, and riots. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> lists the various ways they have demonstrated their faithfulness, such as by purity, knowledge, patience, and the Holy Spirit. He urges the Corinthians to be separate from unbelievers and not to be unequally yoked with them. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> reminds them that they are the temple of the living God, calling them to live holy lives in accordance with their identity as God’s people.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his joy over the Corinthians’ response to his previous letter, which addressed their issues and sin. He talks about the sorrow that leads to repentance, contrasting it with worldly sorrow that brings death. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> mentions that he had been troubled and anxious about their reaction, but he is relieved to find that they have repented and restored their relationship with God. He expresses his deep affection for them and his confidence in their commitment to the Gospel.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the Corinthians to participate in the collection for the believers in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> who are in need. He uses the example of the churches in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who, despite their own poverty, gave generously. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that giving should come from the heart and according to one’s ability. He also reminds them of the grace of our Lord <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ, who, though rich, became poor for their sake. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> assures the Corinthians that he is sending <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink></jLink></jLink> and others to help facilitate the collection and to ensure that their generosity is recognized.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> continues discussing the collection and prepares the Corinthians for the upcoming gift. He encourages them to give cheerfully, not reluctantly or under compulsion, as God loves a cheerful giver. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> assures them that God will provide for their needs and that their generosity will result in thanksgiving to God. He emphasizes that their giving is a way to glorify God and strengthen the bond among believers. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes by expressing his gratitude for the Corinthians’ willingness to help and for the praise that will be given to God as a result.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> defends his authority as an apostle. He addresses criticisms from some who claim he is weak in person but bold in letters. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> explains that he does not wage war as the world does but relies on spiritual weapons to demolish strongholds and arguments against the knowledge of God. He emphasizes that his authority is given by God, not for destruction but for building up the Church. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> urges the Corinthians to be obedient and to not compare themselves with others.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his concern for the Corinthians, who have been influenced by false apostles and deceitful workers. He speaks of his own credentials, listing his sufferings, such as beatings, shipwrecks, and danger from various enemies. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes his dedication to the Gospel and his love for the Corinthians. He presents himself as a true servant of Christ, contrasting himself with the false apostles who boast about their achievements. He underscores the importance of recognizing true authority in the Church.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> speaks about a "thorn in the flesh" that he has endured, which he describes as a messenger of Satan. He shares that he pleaded with the Lord three times to remove it, but God replied that His grace is sufficient. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> learns to boast in his weaknesses, as they allow Christ’s power to be evident in his life. He recounts visions and revelations he has received but chooses not to boast about them. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his concern for the Corinthians and his desire to visit them again, urging them to examine themselves in their faith.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> prepares to visit the Corinthians for a third time. He warns that he will not spare those who have sinned and have not repented. He emphasizes the importance of living in obedience to Christ and encourages them to test their faith. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes with a call for unity and peace among the believers. He sends greetings and expresses his hope that the grace of the Lord <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit will be with them.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> introduces himself and states that he is an apostle, not appointed by humans but by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ and God the Father. He expresses astonishment that the Galatians are turning away from the true Gospel to follow a different one, which he says is no Gospel at all. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> warns that anyone preaching a different Gospel, even if it is an angel, should be cursed. He shares his own testimony, explaining how he was once a zealous Jew, persecuting the Church, but was called by God’s grace to preach the Gospel to the Gentiles. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that his message was received through revelation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, not from human sources.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> describes his visit to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> to meet with prominent apostles like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> (Cephas), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler>John</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He discusses the issue of circumcision and whether Gentiles must follow Jewish laws. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> defends the truth of the Gospel and explains that he was accepted by the leaders in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He recounts an incident where he confronted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> for withdrawing from eating with Gentiles out of fear of the circumcision group. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> stresses that righteousness comes through faith in Christ, not by observing the law. He concludes that if righteousness could be gained through the law, then Christ died for nothing.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins by questioning the Galatians about their foolishness for turning away from the true Gospel. He reminds them that they received the Holy Spirit by believing in Christ, not by following the law. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> uses the example of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who was considered righteous because of his faith. He explains that the law was given later and does not nullify the promise made to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that through faith in Christ, believers are children of God and heirs to the promises given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> continues discussing the status of believers as children of God. He compares the former life under the law to being in slavery and contrasts it with the freedom that comes through faith in Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his concern that the Galatians are turning back to weak and miserable forces, observing special days and seasons. He reminds them of his deep affection for them and how they received him as a messenger of God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> uses the story of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink></jLink></jLink> to illustrate the difference between living under the law (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the slave woman) and living in freedom (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the free woman). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> urges the Galatians to stand firm in their freedom and not to be burdened again by the yoke of slavery (the law). He encourages them to run the race of faith and not be hindered by false teachings. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> also discusses the fruits of the Spirit, contrasting them with the acts of the flesh. He lists the fruits of the Spirit, such as love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control, urging them to live by the Spirit.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> provides practical instructions for the community of believers. He encourages them to gently restore anyone caught in sin and to carry each other’s burdens. He reminds them that they will reap what they sow, emphasizing the importance of doing good to all, especially fellow believers. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> concludes the letter by emphasizing his own marks of suffering for Christ and expressing his desire for the Galatians to be free from legalism. He encourages them to rely on the grace of our Lord <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins with a greeting and praises God for the spiritual blessings bestowed on believers in Christ. He speaks of God choosing us before the foundation of the world to be holy and blameless. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> highlights that through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>' blood, believers receive redemption and forgiveness of sins. He explains that God has revealed the mystery of His will, which is to bring unity to all things in heaven and on earth under Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> also emphasizes that believers are sealed with the Holy Spirit, guaranteeing their inheritance. He concludes the chapter by praying that the Ephesians may know the hope of their calling, the riches of God's glorious inheritance, and His incomparably great power for those who believe.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> explains the transformation from death to life that believers experience through faith in Christ. He describes how all were once dead in their sins and followed the ways of the world. However, God, in His great love, made us alive with Christ, even when we were dead in transgressions. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that salvation is a gift from God, not based on our works. He stresses that believers are God’s handiwork, created in Christ for good works. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> also speaks about the unity of Jews and Gentiles in Christ, highlighting that both groups are reconciled and have access to God through the Holy Spirit. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> shares his mission to the Gentiles, explaining that the mystery of Christ was revealed to him. He emphasizes that through the Gospel, Gentiles are heirs together with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink> and members of one body. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his deep prayer for the Ephesians, asking that they may be strengthened in their inner being through the Holy Spirit. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> urges the Ephesians to live a life worthy of their calling. He emphasizes the importance of unity in the body of Christ, encouraging them to be humble, gentle, and patient. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses the gifts given to the Church, including apostles, prophets, evangelists, pastors, and teachers, all aimed at equipping believers for works of service and building up the body of Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> continues to encourage the Ephesians to live as children of light. He encourages them to be filled with the Spirit, speaking to one another in psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> also discusses the relationship between husbands and wives, comparing it to the relationship between Christ and the Church. He instructs wives to submit to their husbands and husbands to love their wives sacrificially.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the relationship between children and parents, instructing children to obey their parents, as this is right. He also instructs fathers not to provoke their children but to raise them in the training and instruction of the Lord. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> then speaks to slaves and masters, urging slaves to serve wholeheartedly and masters to treat their slaves with respect. The chapter concludes with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discussing the armor of God. He instructs believers to put on the full armor of God to stand against the devil's schemes. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> describes each piece of the armor, emphasizing prayer and vigilance in spiritual warfare.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins by greeting the Philippians and expressing gratitude for their partnership in the Gospel. He shares that he is in prison but sees it as an opportunity to advance the Gospel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that his imprisonment has encouraged others to speak the word of God more boldly. He mentions the mixed reactions to his situation: some preach Christ out of goodwill, while others do so from envy. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> rejoices that, regardless of the motives, Christ is being preached. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the Philippians to have unity and humility. He urges them to adopt the same mindset as Christ, who humbled Himself and became a servant, even to the point of death on a cross. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> highlights that God exalted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> and gave Him the name above all names.
