<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> warns against false teachers and emphasizes the importance of true faith. He shares his background as a Pharisee, listing his achievements and qualifications, but states that he considers them worthless compared to knowing Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his desire to know Christ and the power of His resurrection, sharing in His sufferings and becoming like Him in His death. He encourages the Philippians to press on toward the goal of the heavenly prize in Christ <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> and to imitate his example. He warns them that some live as enemies of the cross, focused on earthly things.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses specific issues in the Church, urging <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2136' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2136' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2136' clickHandler>Euodia</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4941' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4941' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4941' clickHandler>Syntyche</jLink></jLink></jLink> to agree in the Lord. He encourages the Philippians to rejoice always and not be anxious, but to pray about everything. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> reminds them to think about whatever is true, noble, right, and pure. He expresses gratitude for their support and generosity, particularly in sending gifts while he was in need. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> assures them that God will meet all their needs according to His riches in glory. He concludes with personal greetings and a blessing of grace.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins with a greeting and expresses gratitude for the faith of the Colossians. He prays for them, asking God to fill them with knowledge and wisdom. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes the supremacy of Christ, describing Him as the image of the invisible God and the firstborn over all creation. He explains that through Christ, all things were created, and He holds everything together. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> shares that believers have been rescued from the dominion of darkness and brought into the kingdom of the Son. He concludes the chapter by discussing his role as a servant of the Gospel and his struggles for the believers.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> warns the Colossians against false teachings and philosophies that distract from Christ. He emphasizes the fullness of God dwelling in Christ and encourages the believers to be rooted and built up in Him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> discusses the importance of being free from legalism and the traditions of men, reminding them that they have been made alive in Christ. He encourages them not to let anyone judge them regarding religious festivals or dietary laws, as these are shadows of what was to come.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> instructs the Colossians to set their minds on things above, not on earthly things. He emphasizes that they have died with Christ and their lives are hidden with Him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages them to put to death their earthly nature, such as sexual immorality and anger, and to clothe themselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> provides final instructions and personal greetings. He encourages the Colossians to be devoted to prayer and to be watchful and thankful. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> asks them to pray for him, that he may proclaim the Gospel clearly. He concludes with personal greetings to various individuals, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0708' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0708' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0708' clickHandler>Aristarchus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3065' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3065' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3065' clickHandler>Luke</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes the importance of encouraging one another and sharing the message of Christ.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> begins by greeting the Thessalonian church and expressing gratitude for their faith, love, and hope. He commends them for their work produced by faith and their labor prompted by love. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> shares how the Gospel came to them not only in words but also in power and the Holy Spirit, leading to their transformation. The Thessalonians became an example to all believers in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler>Achaia</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> highlights their turn from idols to serve the living God and to wait for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who delivers them from the coming wrath.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> reflects on his time in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2332' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2332' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2332' clickHandler>Thessalonica</jLink></jLink></jLink>, defending his ministry against accusations. He emphasizes that he did not come with deceit or flattery but preached the Gospel boldly, despite suffering. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his deep affection for the Thessalonians, comparing his relationship with them to that of a nursing mother and her children. He recalls how he worked day and night to support himself while sharing the Gospel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages them to stand firm in their faith and praises them for accepting the message as the word of God.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses concern for the Thessalonians and sends <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink></jLink></jLink> to strengthen and encourage them in their faith. The main purpose of the letter is to address <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler>Onesimus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who has escaped from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink></jLink></jLink> and has since become a believer while with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> in prison. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> refers to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler>Onesimus</jLink></jLink></jLink> as "my very heart" and asks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink></jLink></jLink> to receive him back, not just as a slave but as a beloved brother in Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses his willingness to pay any debts that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler>Onesimus</jLink></jLink></jLink> owes and emphasizes the importance of forgiveness and reconciliation. He encourages <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink></jLink></jLink> to act in accordance with love and to refresh the hearts of believers. The letter concludes with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink></jLink></jLink> expressing confidence that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink></jLink></jLink> will do even more than he asks and includes personal greetings.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, Higher than Angels: The author begins by establishing the divinity of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He states that in the past, God spoke through prophets, but now He speaks through His Son, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. The chapter highlights that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is superior to the angels, as He is the Son of God. The author quotes various Old Testament scriptures to support this claim, showing that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is worshipped by angels and holds authority over all creation.¶This chapter emphasizes the greatness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> and sets the stage for understanding His role in salvation.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> as Our Savior: Continues by explaining the significance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s humanity. The author notes that, although <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is divine, He became human to save humanity from sin. By suffering and dying, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> tasted death for everyone, providing salvation.¶The chapter also discusses the importance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> being a faithful High Priest, who understands human suffering and temptation. The author encourages believers to pay attention to the message of salvation and not to drift away from it. This chapter reinforces the central message of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> as the Savior.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Greater than <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>: The author compares <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a significant figure in Jewish history. While <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink> was faithful as a servant in God’s house, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is faithful as the Son over God’s house. This chapter emphasizes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> deserves greater honor than <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶The author warns the believers not to harden their hearts as the Israelites did during their time in the wilderness. He encourages them to hold firmly to their faith in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> and to encourage one another. The chapter concludes with a reminder of the importance of remaining faithful to God.

The Promise of Rest: The author speaks about the rest that God promises to His people. He refers to the Israelites who wandered in the wilderness and did not enter the Promised Land due to their unbelief. The chapter emphasizes the importance of faith in entering this rest.¶The author encourages believers to strive to enter God’s rest by being faithful and obedient. He also explains that the Word of God is alive and powerful, able to judge the thoughts and intentions of the heart. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is presented as the great High Priest who can sympathize with our weaknesses because He was tempted in every way but did not sin.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> as High Priest: Discusses the role of the High Priest. The author explains that a High Priest is chosen from among people to represent them before God. He mentions <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the first High Priest, as an example.¶The chapter states that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is a High Priest in the order of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a mysterious figure from the Old Testament. The author emphasizes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> learned obedience through suffering and was designated by God as the High Priest. The chapter also warns that the readers should grow in their understanding of the Christian faith and not remain as spiritual infants.

Assurance of Hope: The author encourages the believers to move beyond basic teachings and to grow in their faith. He warns against falling away and emphasizes the importance of perseverance.¶The author assures them that God is faithful and will not forget their work and love. He encourages them to hold on to the hope set before them, which is an anchor for the soul. The chapter highlights the certainty of God’s promises and the importance of faith.

The Order of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink>: Delves deeper into the figure of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who was both a king and a priest. The author explains how <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink> blessed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>, showing his greatness.¶He contrasts <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink> with the Levitical priests, stating that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, as a priest in the order of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink></jLink></jLink>, has a superior priesthood. This means that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s priesthood is eternal and does not depend on genealogy. The chapter emphasizes the superiority of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s sacrifice and His ability to save completely.

The New Covenant: The author speaks of a new covenant that God has established through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. This new covenant is superior to the old covenant, which was based on the Law given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>.¶The author quotes the prophet Jeremiah, stating that God will write His laws on the hearts and minds of His people. This new covenant provides a more intimate relationship with God, where sins are forgiven, and there is no need for continual sacrifices. The chapter emphasizes the transformative nature of the new covenant in Christ.

The Sacrificial System: Discusses the old sacrificial system and the tabernacle where sacrifices were made. The author explains that the blood of animals could not fully take away sin.¶He highlights that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> entered the true sanctuary in heaven and offered His own blood as the perfect sacrifice for sin. This act of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> provides eternal redemption for believers. The chapter concludes by stating that Christ will return not to bear sin again but to bring salvation to those who are waiting for Him.

The Final Sacrifice: The author emphasizes that the sacrifices made under the old covenant were insufficient. He highlights that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s sacrifice was once and for all, fulfilling the requirements of the Law.¶The chapter encourages believers to draw near to God with confidence and to hold fast to their faith. It warns against forsaking the gathering of believers and encourages mutual encouragement. The author reminds them of the importance of perseverance and the certainty of God’s promises.

The Hall of Faith: Often called the "Hall of Faith" as it lists many examples of faithful individuals from the Old Testament. The chapter begins by defining faith as the assurance of things hoped for and the conviction of things not seen.¶The author mentions several key figures, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and many others, highlighting their acts of faith and the promises they believed in. These examples serve to encourage believers to remain steadfast in their faith, as they can look to these heroes of faith for inspiration.

Perseverance in Faith: The author encourages believers to persevere in their faith. He begins by urging them to run the race set before them, looking to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> as the perfect example. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> endured suffering and shame for the joy set before Him, demonstrating the importance of focusing on God's promises.¶The author also discusses the discipline of God, comparing it to a loving father who corrects his children. This discipline is intended for their growth and should be seen as a sign of God’s love. The chapter emphasizes that enduring hardship is part of the Christian journey and that it leads to righteousness and peace.¶Additionally, the author warns against bitterness and encourages the community to strengthen one another. He highlights the importance of holiness and living in a way that reflects God's character. Key figures mentioned include <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and the chapter draws on the experiences of the faithful from the past.

Instructions for Christian Living: The author gives practical instructions for living a Christian life. He begins by emphasizing the importance of love and hospitality, encouraging believers to show kindness to strangers, as some have entertained angels without knowing it.¶The chapter addresses various topics, including honoring marriage, avoiding greed, and being content with what one has. The author reminds the community that God will never leave or forsake them, providing reassurance of His presence.¶The writer also encourages the believers to remember their leaders and to imitate their faith. He emphasizes the importance of sound teaching and warns against strange doctrines. The chapter concludes with a prayer for the community and a blessing, affirming the power of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>’s sacrifice.

Testing and Wisdom: The author, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink></jLink></jLink>, identifies himself as a servant of God and introduces the letter. He discusses the importance of testing in the life of a believer, stating that trials produce perseverance, which leads to maturity and completeness. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages believers to consider it pure joy when facing trials, as they strengthen their faith.¶The chapter also emphasizes the need for wisdom. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink></jLink></jLink> states that anyone lacking wisdom should ask God, who gives generously without finding fault. He teaches that faith must be accompanied by action, warning against doubt when asking God for wisdom. Additionally, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the temporary nature of wealth and encourages the poor to take pride in their high position in Christ.

Faith and Works: Discusses the relationship between faith and works. James warns against favoritism within the church, stating that believers should treat everyone equally, regardless of their social status. He emphasizes that faith without works is dead, meaning that genuine faith is demonstrated through actions.¶James uses the example of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who was justified by his works when he offered his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He also mentions <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7343' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7343' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7343' clickHandler>Rahab</jLink></jLink></jLink>, a prostitute who was justified by her actions when she hid the spies. This chapter highlights the necessity of living out one’s faith through good deeds.

Taming the Tongue: The author focuses on the power of the tongue. He warns that teachers will be judged more strictly and emphasizes the importance of controlling one’s speech. The chapter discusses how the tongue can be both a blessing and a curse, capable of causing great harm or great good.¶James compares the tongue to a small fire that can set a great forest ablaze. He encourages believers to use their words wisely and to seek wisdom from above, which is pure and peace-loving. The chapter highlights the need for humility and the importance of living a life that reflects God’s wisdom.

Humility and Submission: The author addresses conflicts and desires among believers. He explains that quarrels and fights often arise from selfish desires. James calls for humility and submission to God, encouraging believers to resist the devil and draw near to God.¶He teaches about the importance of repentance and warns against speaking evil of one another. The chapter emphasizes the need for humility before God and the recognition of human limitations.

Prayer and Patience: The author discusses the importance of prayer and patience in times of suffering. He encourages believers to pray for one another and to confess their sins. James highlights the power of prayer, stating that the prayer of a righteous person is powerful and effective.¶He also encourages patience in the face of suffering, using the examples of the prophets and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0347' clickHandler>Job</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who remained steadfast in their trials. The chapter concludes with a call to restore those who wander from the truth and emphasizes the importance of community support and love.

Living Hope: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the Christians scattered in various regions, including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4195' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4195' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4195' clickHandler>Pontus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1053' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1053' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1053' clickHandler>Galatia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2587' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2587' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2587' clickHandler>Cappadocia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0978' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0978' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0978' clickHandler>Bithynia</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He begins by reminding them of their living hope through the resurrection of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that they have been born again and have an inheritance that is imperishable and kept in heaven for them.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the believers to rejoice in their trials, as these hardships will test their faith and result in praise and glory when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is revealed. He also highlights the prophets who spoke of the grace to come and how they searched diligently to understand it. The chapter concludes with a call to be holy, as God is holy, and to love one another deeply.

A Chosen People: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> describes believers as a royal priesthood and a holy nation. He encourages them to crave spiritual milk, so they can grow in their faith. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> reminds them that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is the cornerstone, rejected by men but chosen by God.¶He instructs believers to live good lives among the pagans, so that even if they are accused of wrongdoing, their good deeds will glorify God. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the topic of submission, urging believers to submit to human authorities, such as kings and governors, as a way to honor God. The chapter emphasizes the importance of living honorably and serving others.

Suffering for Doing Good: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> speaks about the relationships between husbands and wives, encouraging mutual respect and understanding. He emphasizes the importance of inner beauty and a gentle spirit for women.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> also encourages believers to be prepared to give an answer for their hope in Christ, doing so with gentleness and respect. He reminds them that it is better to suffer for doing good than for doing evil. The chapter concludes with the example of Christ, who suffered for sins but was raised to life.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages believers to live for God and not for sinful desires. He reminds them that they have spent enough time in the past doing what pagans choose to do. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes the importance of being prepared to suffer for being a Christian, stating that suffering can lead to joy and glory. He encourages believers to use their gifts to serve others and to glorify God in all things. The chapter concludes with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> reminding them not to be surprised by trials and to trust in God, who will restore them.

Shepherding the Flock: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the elders of the church, urging them to shepherd God’s flock willingly and with humility. He emphasizes that they should not lord over those entrusted to them but lead by example.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages younger believers to submit to their elders and to clothe themselves with humility toward one another. He reminds them to cast all their anxieties on God because He cares for them. The chapter concludes with a call to resist the devil and stand firm in faith, knowing that fellow believers are undergoing similar sufferings.

Growing in Knowledge: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes the importance of growing in knowledge and virtue. He reminds believers that God has given them everything they need for life and godliness through their knowledge of Him.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages believers to add to their faith goodness, knowledge, self-control, perseverance, godliness, mutual affection, and love. He stresses that those who possess these qualities will be effective and productive in their knowledge of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> also mentions the importance of remembering the prophecies and teachings of the apostles.

Warning Against False Teachers: Warns against false prophets and teachers who will secretly introduce destructive heresies. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> describes the characteristics of these false teachers, stating that they will exploit believers with fabricated stories.¶He reminds readers of the judgment that came upon the ancient world, such as the flood in the days of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink></jLink></jLink> and the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6017' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6017' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6017' clickHandler>Gomorrah</jLink></jLink></jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> emphasizes that God knows how to rescue the godly and hold the unrighteous for punishment. This chapter serves as a stern warning to be vigilant against misleading teachings.

The Day of the Lord: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> addresses the delayed return of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He explains that the Lord is not slow in keeping His promise but is patient, wanting everyone to come to repentance.¶<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages believers to live holy and godly lives as they look forward to the day of the Lord, which will come unexpectedly. He reminds them that the heavens and earth will be destroyed, and a new heaven and new earth will be established. The chapter concludes with an encouragement to grow in grace and knowledge of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ.

Fellowship with God: John begins by declaring the reality of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ, who was from the beginning and was seen and heard by the apostles. He emphasizes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is the Word of life, and through Him, believers can have fellowship with God and with one another.¶John explains that God is light, and in Him, there is no darkness at all. He encourages believers to walk in the light, meaning to live transparently and honestly, confessing their sins. John assures them that if they confess their sins, God is faithful and just to forgive them. This chapter sets the foundation for understanding the importance of living in truth and light.

Obedience and Love: John emphasizes the necessity of obedience to God's commands as evidence of knowing Him. He writes that if anyone claims to know God but does not keep His commands, that person is a liar. He also stresses the importance of loving one another, stating that love is central to the Christian faith.¶John warns against the love of the world, which includes desires of the flesh, desires of the eyes, and pride in possessions. He reminds believers that the world and its desires pass away, but whoever does the will of God lives forever. The chapter also addresses the emergence of false teachers, urging believers to remain rooted in the truth they have received.

Children of God: John explains that believers are called children of God and emphasizes the incredible love that God has for them. He notes that the world does not recognize them because it did not recognize Him.¶John highlights the importance of purity, stating that everyone who has this hope in Christ purifies themselves just as He is pure. He warns against sin, explaining that sin is lawlessness. John encourages believers to practice righteousness and not to be like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who killed his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink></jLink></jLink> out of jealousy. The chapter emphasizes the necessity of love, stating that anyone who does not love remains in death.

Love and Discernment: John focuses on the theme of love. He states that God is love, and anyone who loves is born of God and knows God. John emphasizes that the love of God was revealed through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ, who gave His life for humanity.¶He encourages believers to love one another, as love comes from God. John also warns about false spirits and teaches the importance of testing the spirits to see whether they are from God. He explains that anyone who does not acknowledge <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ has the spirit of the antichrist. The chapter assures believers that perfect love casts out fear, as fear involves punishment.

Faith and Victory: John concludes his letter by affirming that everyone who believes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> is the Christ is born of God. He emphasizes the importance of loving God and obeying His commands, stating that love for God is demonstrated through keeping His commandments.¶John reassures believers that they have victory over the world through their faith. He reminds them of the testimony of God about His Son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who came by water and blood. The chapter concludes with a strong affirmation of eternal life, stating that those who have the Son have life, while those who do not have the Son do not have life.

Love and Caution:  A brief letter written by John, who identifies himself as "the elder." He addresses the letter to "the chosen lady and her children," which may refer to a specific church and its members or could represent a metaphor for the church as a whole.¶In this letter, John emphasizes the command to love one another as a fundamental principle of the Christian faith. He highlights that love is not just a feeling but involves obedience to God's commands. John warns the recipients to be vigilant against deceivers who do not acknowledge that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ came in the flesh. He instructs them not to welcome such individuals into their homes or churches, as doing so could lead to sharing in their wicked work.¶John expresses his desire to talk to them face-to-face, stating that he has much to share but prefers to do so in person rather than through writing. The letter concludes with a greeting from the children of the chosen sister, reinforcing the theme of community and shared faith.

Christian Hospitality:  A short letter written by John, again identifying himself as "the elder." This letter is addressed to a man named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink></jLink></jLink>, whom John praises for his faithfulness and love towards others, especially fellow believers.¶John acknowledges the good deeds of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who is showing hospitality to traveling Christians, likely missionaries. He commends <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink></jLink></jLink> for supporting these workers in their journey for Christ. John emphasizes the importance of Christian hospitality, encouraging <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink></jLink></jLink> to continue his generous support of those who proclaim the truth.¶The letter also mentions <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1361' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1361' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1361' clickHandler>Diotrephes</jLink></jLink></jLink>, who is described as someone who loves to be first and refuses to welcome the brothers, causing divisions in the church. John expresses his intention to confront <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1361' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1361' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1361' clickHandler>Diotrephes</jLink></jLink></jLink> when he arrives, highlighting the need for unity and love within the Christian community.

<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink></jLink></jLink> introduces himself as a servant of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ and a brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink></jLink></jLink>. He addresses the letter to those who are called, loved by God the Father, and kept for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink></jLink></jLink> expresses a desire to write about the salvation they share, but instead, he feels compelled to urge believers to contend for the faith that has been entrusted to them. He warns them to be careful of false teachers who have secretly infiltrated the church, turning the grace of God into a license for immorality and denying <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink></jLink></jLink> recalls examples from history, including the Israelites who were delivered from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink> but later destroyed because of unbelief, and the angels who rebelled and were cast into darkness. He warns that these false teachers will face judgment and describes their characteristics, such as being grumblers and faultfinders. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages believers to remain faithful, build themselves up in their faith, and pray in the Holy Spirit. He concludes by urging them to show mercy to those who doubt and to save others by snatching them from the fire. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink></jLink></jLink> ends with a doxology, praising God for His glory, majesty, power, and authority.

Introduction and Vision of Christ: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler>John</jLink></jLink></jLink> introduces himself and addresses the seven churches in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink></jLink></jLink> Minor (modern-day Turkey). He describes a vision of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ, who appears glorified, with white hair, eyes like flames, and a voice like rushing waters. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> holds seven stars and walks among seven lampstands, representing the churches. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler>John</jLink></jLink></jLink> is instructed to write down what he sees and send it to the churches.

Messages to the Seven Churches (Part 1): John records messages from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> to the first four of the seven churches.¶<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> commends the church for its hard work but criticizes it for losing its first love. He calls for repentance and reminds them to return to their initial passion for God.¶<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4667' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4667' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4667' clickHandler>Smyrna</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages the church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4667' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4667' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4667' clickHandler>Smyrna</jLink></jLink></jLink>, acknowledging their suffering and poverty but assuring them of their spiritual richness. He warns them about impending persecution but promises the crown of life to those who remain faithful.¶<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4010' clickHandler>Pergamum</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> acknowledges the faithfulness of the church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4010' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4010' clickHandler>Pergamum</jLink></jLink></jLink> despite living in a city where Satan has his throne. However, He criticizes them for allowing false teachings and immorality to spread. He urges them to repent.¶<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2363' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2363' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2363' clickHandler>Thyatira</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> praises the church for its love and service but condemns it for tolerating a false prophetess named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink></jLink></jLink> who leads believers into sexual immorality. He warns of judgment if they do not repent.

Messages to the Seven Churches (Part 2): Continues with messages to the remaining three churches:¶Sardis: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> warns the church in Sardis that it appears alive but is spiritually dead. He calls them to wake up, strengthen what remains, and remember the teachings they received.¶<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5359' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5359' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5359' clickHandler>Philadelphia</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> commends the faithful church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5359' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5359' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5359' clickHandler>Philadelphia</jLink></jLink></jLink> for their perseverance and promises to protect them during the time of trial. He assures them that those who are not true believers will acknowledge them as God's people.¶<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2993' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2993' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2993' clickHandler>Laodicea</jLink></jLink></jLink>: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> rebukes the lukewarm church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2993' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2993' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2993' clickHandler>Laodicea</jLink></jLink></jLink>, saying they are neither hot nor cold. He urges them to become zealous and repent. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> invites them to open the door to Him, promising fellowship to those who overcome.

The Throne in Heaven: John describes a vision of heaven, where he sees a throne and the one seated on it, surrounded by 24 elders and four living creatures. The elders wear crowns and worship God, proclaiming His holiness. This chapter emphasizes the majesty and sovereignty of God over all creation.

The Scroll and the Lamb: John sees a scroll sealed with seven seals. No one is found worthy to open it until the Lamb, representing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, appears. The Lamb, who was slain, is worthy to open the scroll. The elders and living creatures worship the Lamb, praising Him for redemption and the establishment of a kingdom.

The Seven Seals: Describes the opening of the first six seals on the scroll.¶The first seal reveals a white horse and a rider who conquers.¶The second seal brings a red horse, symbolizing war and bloodshed.¶The third seal reveals a black horse, representing famine.¶The fourth seal brings a pale horse, whose rider is Death.¶The fifth seal shows the souls of martyrs crying out for justice.¶The sixth seal brings cosmic disturbances, such as earthquakes and darkening of the sun.

The Sealing of the 144,000: John sees an angel sealing 144,000 servants of God from the tribes of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, ensuring their protection during the coming judgments. After this, John sees a great multitude from every nation, tribe, people, and language standing before the throne and the Lamb, praising God and expressing their salvation. This chapter emphasizes God's protection and the hope of salvation for all believers.

The Seventh Seal and the Trumpets: The seventh seal is opened, leading to silence in heaven for half an hour. Seven angels are given trumpets to sound, signaling coming judgments. This chapter emphasizes the seriousness of God’s judgments and prepares for the events that follow.

The Fifth and Sixth Trumpets: The fifth trumpet sounds, and a star falls from heaven, unlocking the Abyss. Locusts emerge, tormenting those who do not have the seal of God on their foreheads. The sixth trumpet releases four angels bound at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6578' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6578' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6578' clickHandler>Euphrates</jLink></jLink></jLink> River, leading to the killing of a third of mankind. Despite these judgments, many still do not repent of their sins.

The Mighty Angel and the Little Scroll: John sees a mighty angel descending from heaven. The angel has a rainbow over his head and a face like the sun. He stands on land and sea, holding a little scroll that is open. The angel shouts, and when he does, seven thunders respond. John is instructed not to write down what the thunders say. The angel then declares that there will be no more delay, and the mystery of God will be fulfilled. John is told to take the little scroll from the angel and eat it; it tastes sweet in his mouth but is bitter in his stomach, symbolizing the bittersweet nature of prophecy.

The Two Witnesses and the Seventh Trumpet: The two witnesses, who prophesy for 1,260 days, clothed in sackcloth. They are described as the two olive trees and two lampstands before God. These witnesses have the power to perform miracles, such as shutting the sky and turning water into blood. After their testimony, they are killed by a beast that arises from the abyss. Their bodies lie in the street of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, which is symbolically called <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink></jLink></jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink></jLink></jLink>. After three and a half days, God resurrects them, and they ascend to heaven. The chapter concludes with the sounding of the seventh trumpet, announcing God's kingdom and judgment.

The Woman and the Dragon: John sees a vision of a woman who is about to give birth, and a great red dragon that seeks to devour her child. The woman represents <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israel</jLink></jLink></jLink>, and the child is identified as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> Christ. The dragon, who is identified as Satan, is defeated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4317Q' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4317Q' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4317Q' clickHandler>Michael</jLink></jLink></jLink> and his angels and is cast down to the earth, where he continues to persecute the woman and her offspring.

The Beast from the Sea and the Beast from the Earth: Introduces two beasts that rise up, representing the Antichrist and the False Prophet. The first beast emerges from the sea, having seven heads and ten horns, and is given authority by the dragon (Satan) to rule the world. The second beast, coming from the earth, deceives people and forces them to worship the first beast. This chapter depicts the power and deception of these evil forces that will arise in the end times.

The Lamb and the 144,000: John sees a vision of the Lamb (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>) standing on Mount Zion with the 144,000 who were sealed in Chapter 7. An angel proclaims the eternal gospel, warning people to fear God and worship Him. Another angel announces the fall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, the great city that has corrupted the earth. The chapter ends with a vision of the Son of Man reaping the harvest of the earth, representing God's final judgment.

The Seven Angels with Seven Plagues: John sees another sign in heaven: seven angels with seven plagues, which are the last plagues because with them God’s wrath is completed. The victorious ones who have overcome the beast sing a song of praise to God. They stand by a sea of glass mixed with fire, symbolizing God's judgment and purity.

The Seven Bowl Judgments: The seven angels pour out the seven bowls of God's wrath. The first bowl causes painful sores, the second turns the sea to blood, the third contaminates the fresh water, the fourth scorches people with fire, the fifth plunges the kingdom of the beast into darkness, the sixth dries up the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6578' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6578' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6578' clickHandler>Euphrates</jLink></jLink></jLink> River, and the seventh brings a great earthquake and hail.

The Woman on the Beast: One of the angels shows John the judgment of the great prostitute, who sits on many waters, symbolizing nations and peoples. This woman is described as being drunk with the blood of saints and is associated with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, representing moral corruption and idolatry. The beast she rides has seven heads and ten horns, symbolizing powerful kingdoms. The chapter reveals that the woman will ultimately face judgment and destruction.

The Fall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>: John describes the fall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, symbolizing the corrupt world system and false religion. An angel from heaven proclaims the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, declaring that it has become a dwelling place for demons and a haunt for unclean spirits. The chapter highlights the reasons for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>'s fall, including its luxury, immorality, and persecution of God’s people.¶The kings of the earth, merchants, and sailors mourn the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink> because they profited from her corruption. They witness her downfall from a distance and lament the loss of their wealth and the great city. The chapter ends with a call for God's people to come out of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>, warning them not to share in her sins and to escape her judgment.

The Wedding of the Lamb: Begins with a great multitude in heaven praising God for His judgment on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink></jLink></jLink>. They rejoice because God has avenged the blood of His servants. The chapter then describes the Marriage Supper of the Lamb, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink>, referred to as the Lamb, will be united with His bride, the Church.¶John sees <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> coming on a white horse, called "Faithful and True." He judges and makes war with righteousness. His eyes are like blazing fire, and He wears many crowns. The armies of heaven follow Him, and He strikes down nations with His word. The chapter emphasizes the victory of Christ over evil and the establishment of His reign.

The Thousand Years and Final Judgment: John describes the binding of Satan for a thousand years, during which he cannot deceive the nations. The saints who had been martyred for their faith come to life and reign with Christ during this period. This is referred to as the first resurrection.¶After the thousand years, Satan is released and deceives the nations one last time, gathering them for battle. However, fire comes down from heaven and consumes them. Satan is then thrown into the lake of fire, where the beast and the false prophet have already been cast.¶The chapter concludes with the Great White Throne Judgment, where the dead are judged according to their deeds. Anyone whose name is not found in the Book of Life is thrown into the lake of fire, symbolizing eternal separation from God.

The New Heaven and New Earth: A vision of a new heaven and a new earth, as the first heaven and earth have passed away. New <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink> descends from heaven, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband. God dwells among His people, wiping away every tear and removing pain and death.¶The chapter describes the beauty of New <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>, with streets of gold and gates made of pearls. It emphasizes that nothing impure will enter this city, only those whose names are written in the Lamb’s Book of Life. This new creation represents the fulfillment of God’s promises to His people.

The River of Life and Final Exhortations: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler>John</jLink></jLink></jLink> describes the river of life, flowing from the throne of God and the Lamb in the New <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler><jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink></jLink></jLink>. On either side of the river stands the Tree of Life, which bears fruit every month and whose leaves are for the healing of the nations.¶The chapter confirms that there will be no more curse and that God’s servants will serve Him and see His face. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink></jLink></jLink> declares, "I am coming soon," and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler>John</jLink></jLink></jLink> encourages believers to keep the words of the prophecy of this book. Concludes with a warning against altering the words of the prophecy and a blessing for those who keep it.
